    1. The substance has a low potential for abuse relative to substances in Schedule III;
    2. The substance has currently accepted medical use in treatment in the United States; and
    3. Abuse of the substance may lead to limited physical dependence or psychological dependence relative to the substances in Schedule III.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 19; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.19.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 35-7-1020. Substances included in Schedule IV.

  1. The controlled substances listed in this section are included in Schedule IV. Schedule IV shall consist of the drugs and other substances, by whatever official name, common or usual name, chemical name or brand name designated, listed in this section.
  2. Narcotic drugs. — Unless specifically excepted or unless listed in another schedule, any material, compound, mixture or preparation containing any of the following narcotic drugs, or their salts calculated as the free anhydrous base or alkaloid, in limited quantities as set forth in paragraphs (i) and (ii) of this subsection:
    1. Not more than one (1) milligram of difenoxin and not less than twenty-five (25) micrograms of atropine sulfate per dosage unit;
    2. Dextropropoxyphene (alpha -(+)-4-dimethylamino-1, 2-diphenyl-3-methyl-2- propionoxy-butane).
  3. Depressants. — Unless specifically excepted or unless listed in another schedule, any material, compound, mixture or preparation which contains any quantity of the following substances, including its salts, isomers and salts of isomers whenever the existence of such salts, isomers and salts of isomers is possible within the specific chemical designation:
    1. Alprazolam;
    2. Barbital;
    3. Bromazepam;
    4. Camazepam;
    5. Chloral betaine;
    6. Chloral hydrate;
    7. Chlordiazepoxide;
    8. Clobazam;
    9. Clonazepam;
    10. Clorazepate;
    11. Clotiazepam;
    12. Cloxazolam;
    13. Delorazepam;
    14. Diazepam;
    15. Estazolam;
    16. Ethchlorvynol;
    17. Ethinamate;
    18. Ethyl Loflazepate;
    19. Fludiazepam;
    20. Flunitrazepam;
    21. Flurazepam;
    22. Halazepam;
    23. Haloxazolam;
    24. Ketazolam;
    25. Loprazolam;
    26. Lorazepam;
    27. Lormetazepam;
    28. Mebutamate;
    29. Medazepam;
    30. Meprobamate;
    31. Methohexital;
    32. Methylphenobarbital (mephobarbital);
    33. Nimetazepam;
    34. Nitrazepam;
    35. Nordiazepam;
    36. Oxazepam;
    37. Oxazolam;
    38. Paraldehyde;
    39. Petrichloral;
    40. Phenobarbital;
    41. Pinazepam;
    42. Prazepam;
    43. Temazepam;
    44. Tetrazepam;
    45. Triazolam;
    46. Midazolam;
    47. Quazepam;
    48. Zolpidem;
    49. Zaleplon;
    50. Dichloralphenazone;
    51. Zopiclone;
    52. Fospropofol.
  4. Fenfluramine. — Any material, compound, mixture or preparation which contains any quantity of the following substances, including its salts, isomers whether optical, position or geometric, and salts of isomers when the existence of these salts, isomers and salts of isomers is possible:
    1. Fenfluramine.
  5. Stimulants. — Unless specifically excepted or unless listed in another schedule, any material, compound, mixture or preparation which contains any quantity of the following substances having a stimulant effect on the central nervous system, including its salts, isomers and salts of isomers:
    1. Diethylpropion;
    2. Mazindol;
    3. Pemoline (including organometallic complexes and chelates thereof);
    4. Phentermine;
    5. Pipradrol;
    6. SPA ((-)-1-dimethylamino-1, 2-diphenylethane);
    7. Cathine ((+)-norpseudoephedrine);
    8. Fencamfamin;
    9. Fenproporex;
    10. Mefenorex;
    11. Sibutramine;
    12. Modafinil.
  6. Other substances. — Unless specifically excepted or unless listed in another schedule, any material, compound, mixture or preparation which contains any quantity of the following substances, including its salts:
    1. Pentazocine;
    2. Butorphanol (including its optical isomers);
    3. Carisoprodol;
    4. Tramadol.
  7. The commissioner may except by rule any compound, mixture or preparation containing any depressant substance listed in subsection (c) of this section from the application of all or any part of this act if the compound, mixture or preparation contains one (1) or more active medicinal ingredients not having a depressant effect on the central nervous system and if the admixtures are included therein in combinations, quantity, proportion or concentration that vitiate the potential for abuse of the substance which have a depressant effect on the central nervous system.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 20; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.20; Laws 1973, ch. 222, § 1; 1985, ch. 114, § 1; 1997, ch. 151, § 1; 2001, ch. 88, § 1; 2007, ch. 40, § 1; 2011, ch. 45, § 1.

The 2007 amendment, effective July 1, 2007, added (c)(l) and (c)(li), and made a related change.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in (c)(xxix), substituted “Medazepam” for “Medaxepam”; and added (c)(lii), (f)(iii) and (f)(iv).

Editor's notes. —

There is no paragraph (d)(ii) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 35-7-1002(a)(xxviii).

Application. —

Laws 2011, ch. 45, § 3, provides: “The registration requirements for persons who manufacture, distribute or dispense controlled substances in Wyoming specified in W.S. 35-7-1024, as amended in section 1 of this act, shall apply to all registrations issued or renewed in calendar year 2011.”

§ 35-7-1021. Findings requiring inclusion of substance in Schedule V.

  1. The commissioner shall place a substance in Schedule V if he finds that:
    1. The substance has low potential for abuse relative to the controlled substances listed in Schedule IV;
    2. The substance has currently accepted medical use in treatment in the United States; and
    3. The substance has limited physical dependence or psychological dependence liability relative to the controlled substances listed in Schedule IV.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 21; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.21.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 35-7-1022. Substances included in Schedule V.

  1. The controlled substances listed in this section are included in Schedule V. Schedule V shall consist of the drugs and other substances, by whatever official name, common or usual name, chemical name or brand name designated in this section.
  2. Narcotic drugs containing nonnarcotic active medicinal ingredients. - Any compound, mixture, or preparation containing limited quantities of any of the following narcotic drugs, or their salts calculated as the free anhydrous base or alkaloid, in limited quantities as set forth in paragraphs (i) through (vi) of this subsection which also contains one (1) or more nonnarcotic active medicinal ingredients in sufficient proportion to confer upon the compound, mixture or preparation valuable medicinal qualities other than those possessed by narcotic drugs alone:
    1. Not more than two hundred (200) milligrams of codeine per one hundred (100) milliliters or per one hundred (100) grams;
    2. Not more than one hundred (100) milligrams of dihydrocodeine per one hundred (100) milliliters or per one hundred (100) grams;
    3. Not more than one hundred (100) milligrams of ethylmorphine per one hundred (100) milliliters or per one hundred (100) grams;
    4. Not more than two and five-tenths (2.5) milligrams of diphenoxylate and not less than twenty-five (25) micrograms of atropine sulfate per dosage unit;
    5. Not more than one hundred (100) milligrams of opium per one hundred (100) milliliters or per one hundred (100) grams;
    6. Not more than five-tenths (0.5) milligram of difenoxin and not less than twenty-five (25) micrograms of atropine sulfate per dosage unit.
  3. Narcotic drugs. Unless specifically excepted or unless listed in another schedule, any material, compound, mixture, or preparation containing any of the following narcotic drugs and their salts, as set forth below:
    1. Repealed by Laws 2007, ch. 40, § 2.
  4. Stimulants. Unless specifically exempted or excluded or unless listed in another schedule, any material, compound, mixture, or preparation which contains any quantity of the following substances having a stimulant effect on the central nervous system, including its salts, isomers and salts of isomers:
    1. Pyrovalerone.
  5. Repealed by Laws 2011, ch. 45, § 2.
  6. Depressants. - Unless specifically exempted or excluded or unless listed in another schedule, any material, compound, mixture or preparation which contains any quantity of the following substances having a depressant effect on the central nervous system, including its salts:
    1. Lacosamide [(R)-2-acetoamido-N-benzyl-3-methoxy-propionamide];
    2. Pregabalin [(S)-3-(aminomethyl)-5-methylhexanoic acid].

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 22; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.22; Laws 1973, ch. 222, § 1; 1985, ch. 114, § 1; 1997, ch. 151, § 1; 2007, ch. 40, §§ 1, 2; 2011, ch. 45, §§ 1, 2.

The 2007 amendment, effective July 1, 2007, deleted (c)(i), which read: “Buprenorphine”; and added (e).

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in (b), inserted “Narcotic drugs containing nonnarcotic active medicinal ingredients”; repealed former (e), which read: “Any compound, mixture or preparation containing pregabalin [(S)-3-(aminomethyl)-5- methylhexanoic acid], including its salts, isomers and salts of isomers”; and added (f).

Editor's notes. —

There is no paragraph (c)(ii) or (d)(ii) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Application. —

Article IV

  • § 35-7-1023.  Board of pharmacy to administer registration requirements; rules; fees.
  • § 35-7-1024.  Registration requirements.
  • § 35-7-1025.  Registration of manufacturers and distributors; controlled substance prescription tracking program enrollment.
  • § 35-7-1026.  Suspension or revocation of registration.
  • § 35-7-1027.  Order to show cause before denial, suspension, revocation or refusal to renew registration; emergency suspension.
  • § 35-7-1028.  Records and inventories required of registrants.
  • § 35-7-1029.  Order forms required for distribution of substances in Schedules I and II.
  • § 35-7-1030.  Prescriptions required in certain instances.

§ 35-7-1023. Board of pharmacy to administer registration requirements; rules; fees.

The Wyoming state board of pharmacy shall have the responsibility for administering the registration requirements of this article, and may promulgate rules and charge reasonable fees relating to the registration and control of the manufacture, distribution, and dispensing of controlled substances within this state.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 23; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.23.

§ 35-7-1024. Registration requirements.

  1. Every person who manufactures, distributes or dispenses any controlled substance within this state or who proposes to engage in the manufacture, distribution or dispensing of any controlled substance within this state, must obtain every two (2) years, on or before July 1, a registration issued by the board in accordance with its rules. Any registrant who fails to renew his registration by July 1 of each renewal year shall be charged a late fee. If the failure to renew continues past September 30 of the renewal year, the registration shall be cancelled and the United States drug enforcement administration notified for cancellation of the registrant’s federal registration.
  2. Persons registered by the board under this act to manufacture, distribute, dispense, or conduct research with controlled substances may possess, manufacture, distribute, dispense, or conduct research with those substances to the extent authorized by their registration and in conformity with the other provisions of this article.
  3. The following persons need not register and may lawfully possess controlled substances under this act:
    1. An agent or employee of any registered manufacturer, distributor, or dispenser of any controlled substance if he is acting in the usual course of his legitimate business or employment;
    2. A common or contract carrier or warehouseman, or an employee thereof, whose possession of any controlled substance is in the usual course of business or employment;
    3. An ultimate user or a person in possession of any controlled substance pursuant to a lawful order of a practitioner or in lawful possession of a Schedule V substance.
  4. The board may waive by rule the requirement for registration of certain manufacturers, distributors, or dispensers if it finds it consistent with the public health and safety.
  5. A separate registration is required at each principal place of business or professional practice where the applicant manufactures, distributes, or dispenses controlled substances.
  6. The board may inspect the establishment of a registrant or applicant for registration in accordance with the rules and regulations promulgated by the board.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 24; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.24; Laws 1975, ch. 192, § 1; 1999, ch. 101, § 2; 2011, ch. 45, § 1.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in (a), substituted “every two (2) years” for “annually,” “July 1” for “September 30,” and “renewal year” for “calendar year” twice, deleted “in the amount of forty dollars ($40.00)” at the end of the second sentence, and substituted “September 30” for “December 31” and “United States drug enforcement administration” for “bureau.”

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 35-7-1002(a)(xxviii).

Application. —

Laws 2011, ch. 45, § 3, provides: “The registration requirements for persons who manufacture, distribute or dispense controlled substances in Wyoming specified in W.S. 35-7-1024, as amended in section 1 of this act, shall apply to all registrations issued or renewed in calendar year 2011.”

Dispensing of controlled substance by pharmacist outside of statutory authority. —

See Dover v. State, 664 P.2d 536, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 334 (Wyo. 1983).

Investigatory drug snares immunized. —

The acquisition, use and sale for investigatory purposes, without registration, of marijuana did not violate defendant's right to due process where the technical violations at issue were implicitly immunized under § 35-7-1043 as legitimate investigatory drug snares. Rivera v. State, 846 P.2d 1, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 1993).

§ 35-7-1025. Registration of manufacturers and distributors; controlled substance prescription tracking program enrollment.

  1. The board shall register an applicant to manufacture or distribute controlled substances included in W.S. 35-7-1014, 35-7-1016, 35-7-1018, 35-7-1020 and 35-7-1022 unless it determines that the issuance of that registration would be inconsistent with the public interest. In determining the public interest, the board shall consider the following factors:
    1. Maintenance of effective controls against diversion of controlled substances into other than legitimate medical, scientific, or industrial channels;
    2. Compliance with applicable state and local law;
    3. Any convictions of the applicant under any federal and state laws relating to any controlled substance;
    4. Past experience in the manufacture or distribution of controlled substances, and the existence in the applicant’s establishment of effective controls against diversion;
    5. Furnishing by the applicant of false or fraudulent material in any application filed under this act;
    6. Suspension or revocation of the applicant’s federal registration to manufacture, distribute, or dispense controlled substances as authorized by federal law; and
    7. Any other factors relevant to and consistent with the public health and safety.
  2. Registration under subsection (a) of this section does not entitle a registrant to manufacture and distribute controlled substances in Schedule I or II other than those specified in the registration.
  3. Practitioners shall be registered to dispense any controlled substances or to conduct research with controlled substances in Schedules II through V if they are authorized to dispense or conduct research under the law of this state. The board need not require separate registration under this article for practitioners engaging in research with nonnarcotic controlled substances in Schedules II through V where the registrant is already registered under this article in another capacity. Practitioners registered under federal law to conduct research with Schedule I substances may conduct research with Schedule I substances within this state upon furnishing the board evidence of that federal registration. The board shall enroll any practitioner registered under this subsection in the controlled substance prescription tracking program maintained by the board under W.S. 35-7-1060 if the practitioner is authorized to dispense any controlled substances in Schedules II through V. The board may promulgate rules and regulations for purposes of enrolling those practitioners in the tracking program.
  4. Compliance by manufacturers and distributors with the provisions of the federal law respecting registration (excluding fees) entitles them to be registered under this act.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 25; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.25; 2018 ch. 96, § 1, effective March 14, 2018.

The 2018 amendment, in (c), substituted “shall” for “must” following “Practitioners” and added the last two sentences.

Laws 2018, ch. 96, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 14, 2018.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 35-7-1002(a)(xxviii).

§ 35-7-1026. Suspension or revocation of registration.

  1. A registration under W.S. 35-7-1025 to manufacture, distribute or dispense a controlled substance may be suspended or revoked by the board upon a finding that the registrant:
    1. Has furnished false or fraudulent material information in any application filed under this act;
    2. Has been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude under any state or federal law relating to any controlled substance;
    3. Has had his federal registration suspended or revoked to manufacture, distribute or dispense controlled substances;
    4. Has willfully violated any of the provisions of this act, or any rules and regulations relating to controlled substances;
    5. Has failed to provide adequate security for the storage of controlled substances to the extent that repeated diversions have occurred; or
    6. Has voluntarily surrendered his license to practice, or has had his license revoked or suspended, or the renewal thereof has been denied or lapsed for cause by his professional licensing board.
  2. The board may limit revocation or suspension of a registration to the particular controlled substance with respect to which grounds for revocation or suspension exist.
  3. If the board suspends or revokes a registration, all controlled substances owned or possessed by the registrant at the time of suspension or the effective date of the revocation order may be placed under seal. No disposition may be made of substances under seal until the time for taking an appeal has elapsed or until all appeals have been concluded unless a court, upon application therefor, orders the sale of perishable substances and the deposit of the proceeds of the sale with the court. Upon a revocation order becoming final, all controlled substances may be forfeited to the state.
  4. The board shall promptly notify the bureau of all orders suspending or revoking registration and all forfeitures of controlled substances.
  5. In the case of a revocation or suspension sought by the board’s staff under paragraph (a)(ii), (iii) or (vi) of this section, a copy of an order or other appropriate documents from a court or administrative agency, certified by the clerk, judge, secretary or executive director thereof, evidencing a revocation, suspension, voluntary suspension or conviction of a felony, shall be conclusive evidence of the conviction, revocation or suspension of the federal registration, or the loss of the license to practice.
  6. The board, by regulation, may adopt procedures under which the denial, suspension, revocation or denial of renewal of a registration may be resolved by mutual agreement between the registrant or applicant and the board’s staff, subject to prior approval by the board.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 26; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.26; Laws 1975, ch. 192, § 1; 2001, ch. 87, § 1.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 35-7-1002(a)(xxviii).

§ 35-7-1027. Order to show cause before denial, suspension, revocation or refusal to renew registration; emergency suspension.

  1. Before denying, suspending, or revoking a registration, or refusing a renewal of registration, the board shall serve upon the applicant or registrant an order to show cause why registration should not be denied, revoked or suspended, or why the renewal should not be refused. The order to show cause shall contain a statement of the basis therefor and shall call upon the applicant or registrant to appear before the board at a time and place not less than thirty (30) days after the date of service of the order, but in the case of a denial or renewal of registration the show cause order shall be served not later than thirty (30) days before the expiration of the registration. These proceedings shall be conducted in accordance with the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act [§§ 16-3-101 through 16-3-115] without regard to any criminal prosecution or other proceeding. Proceedings to refuse renewal of registration shall not abate the existing registration which shall remain in effect pending the outcome of the administrative hearing.
  2. The board may suspend, without an order to show cause, any registration simultaneously with the institution of proceedings under W.S. 35-7-1026, or where renewal of registration is refused, if it finds there is imminent danger to the public health or safety which warrants this action. The suspension shall continue in effect until the conclusion of the proceedings, including judicial review thereof, unless sooner withdrawn by the board or dissolved by a court of competent jurisdiction.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 27; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.27.

§ 35-7-1028. Records and inventories required of registrants.

Persons registered to manufacture, distribute, or dispense controlled substances under this act shall keep records and maintain inventories in conformance with the record-keeping and inventory requirements of federal law and with any additional rules the board issues.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 28; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.28.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 35-7-1002(a)(xxviii).

§ 35-7-1029. Order forms required for distribution of substances in Schedules I and II.

Controlled substances in Schedules I and II shall be distributed by a registrant to another registrant only pursuant to an order form. Compliance with the provisions of federal law respecting order forms shall be deemed compliance with this section.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 29; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.29.

§ 35-7-1030. Prescriptions required in certain instances.

  1. Repealed by Laws 2019, ch. 153, § 1.
  2. In emergency situations, as defined by rule of the board, Schedule II drugs may be dispensed upon oral prescription of a practitioner, reduced promptly to writing and filed by the pharmacy. Prescriptions shall be retained in conformity with the requirements of W.S. 35-7-1028. No prescription for a Schedule II substance may be refilled.
  3. Repealed by Laws 2019, ch. 153, § 1.
  4. No controlled substances included in any schedule may be distributed or dispensed for other than an acceptable medical indication.
  5. No practitioner shall prescribe nor shall any person dispense any opioid or combination of opioids for acute pain to an opioid naive patient for more than a seven (7) day supply in a seven (7) day period. The board shall by rule establish reasonable exceptions to this section, in consultation with other professional licensing boards that license practitioners, including exceptions for chronic pain, cancer treatment, palliative care and other clinically appropriate exceptions. As used in this subsection:
    1. “Opioid” means an opiumlike compound that binds to one (1) or more of the major opioid receptors in the body;
    2. “Opioid naive patient” means a patient who has not had an active opioid prescription in the preceding forty-five (45) day period.
  6. On and after January 1, 2021, except when dispensed directly by a practitioner other than a pharmacy to an ultimate user, no controlled substance included in any schedule shall be dispensed without the electronic prescription of a practitioner. The prescription for a controlled substance included in Schedule III or IV shall not be filled or refilled more than six (6) months after the date of the prescription or be refilled more than five (5) times unless renewed by the practitioner. The board may by rule and regulation provide exemptions from the requirements of this subsection including exemptions for emergencies and technical failures.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 30; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.30; Laws 1975, ch. 192, § 1; 2011, ch. 45, § 1; 2019 ch. 153, § 1, effective July 1, 2019; 2019 ch. 166, § 1, effective July 1, 2019.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in (a) and (c), inserted “or electronic”; and made related changes.

The 2019 amendments. — The first 2019 amendment, by ch. 153, § 1, effective July 1, 2019, in (a) and (c), added the last sentence; and added (f).

The second 2019 amendment, by ch. 166, § 1, effective July 1, 2019, added (e).

This section is set out as reconciled by the Wyoming legislative service office.

The 2019 amendment, by ch. 153, § 1, effective January 1, 2021, repealed former (a), which read, “Except when dispensed directly by a practitioner, other than a pharmacy, to an ultimate user, no controlled substance in Schedule II may be dispensed without the written or electronic prescription of a practitioner. This subsection is repealed effective January 1, 2021.”; and repealed former (c), which read, “Except when dispensed directly by a practitioner other than a pharmacy to an ultimate user, a controlled substance included in Schedule III or IV, which is a prescription drug as determined under state or federal statute, shall not be dispensed without a written, oral or electronic prescription of a practitioner. The prescription shall not be filled or refilled more than six (6) months after the date thereof or be refilled more than five (5) times, unless renewed by the practitioner. This subsection is repealed effective January 1, 2021.”

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Physician's liability to third person for prescribing drug to known drug addict, 42 ALR4th 586.

Article V

  • § 35-7-1031.  Unlawful manufacture or delivery; counterfeit substance; unlawful possession.
  • § 35-7-1032.  Certain unlawful acts particularly applicable to registrants.
  • § 35-7-1033.  Unlawful acts; distribution; registration; possession; records; counterfeiting; punishment. [Effective until July 1, 2024]
  • § 35-7-1033.  Unlawful acts; distribution; registration; possession; records; counterfeiting; punishment. [Effective July 1, 2024]
  • § 35-7-1034.  Penalties are additional.
  • § 35-7-1035.  Conviction or acquittal under federal law or law of another state.
  • § 35-7-1036.  Distribution to person under 18; drug free school zones.
  • § 35-7-1037.  Probation and discharge of first offenders.
  • § 35-7-1038.  Second or subsequent offenses; mandatory minimum penalty for certain subsequent offenses.
  • § 35-7-1039.  Person using or under influence of controlled substance.
  • § 35-7-1040.  Planting, cultivating or processing marihuana, peyote or opium poppy.
  • § 35-7-1041.  Distribution of liquid, substance or material in lieu of controlled substance.
  • § 35-7-1042.  Attempts and conspiracies.
  • § 35-7-1043.  Immunity from prosecution.
  • § 35-7-1044.  Peyote delivered, possessed or used for religious sacramental purposes.

§ 35-7-1031. Unlawful manufacture or delivery; counterfeit substance; unlawful possession.

  1. Except as authorized by this act, it is unlawful for any person to manufacture, deliver, or possess with intent to manufacture or deliver, a controlled substance. Any person who violates this subsection with respect to:
    1. Methamphetamine or a controlled substance classified in Schedule I or II which is a narcotic drug, is guilty of a crime and upon conviction may be imprisoned for not more than twenty (20) years, or fined not more than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), or both;
    2. Any other controlled substance classified in Schedule I, II or III, is guilty of a crime and upon conviction may be imprisoned for not more than ten (10) years, fined not more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), or both;
    3. A substance classified in Schedule IV, is guilty of a crime and upon conviction may be imprisoned for not more than two (2) years, fined not more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00), or both;
    4. A substance classified in Schedule V, is guilty of a crime and upon conviction may be imprisoned for not more than one (1) year, fined not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or both.
  2. Except as authorized by this act, it is unlawful for any person to create, deliver, or possess with intent to deliver, a counterfeit substance. Any person who violates this subsection with respect to:
    1. A counterfeit substance classified in Schedule I or II which is a narcotic drug, is guilty of a crime and upon conviction may be imprisoned for not more than twenty (20) years, fined not more than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), or both;
    2. Any other counterfeit substance classified in Schedule I, II or III, is guilty of a crime and upon conviction may be imprisoned for not more than ten (10) years, fined not more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), or both;
    3. A counterfeit substance classified in Schedule IV, is guilty of a crime and upon conviction may be imprisoned for not more than two (2) years, fined not more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00), or both;
    4. A counterfeit substance classified in Schedule V, is guilty of a crime and upon conviction may be imprisoned for not more than one (1) year, fined not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or both.
  3. It is unlawful  for any person knowingly or intentionally to possess a controlled  substance unless the substance was obtained directly from, or pursuant  to a valid prescription or order of a practitioner while acting in  the course of his professional practice, or except as otherwise authorized  by this act. With the exception of any drug that has received final approval from the United States food  and drug administration, including dronabinol as listed  in W.S. 35-7-1018(h), and notwithstanding any other provision of this act, no practitioner  shall dispense or prescribe marihuana, tetrahydrocannabinol, or synthetic  equivalents of marihuana or tetrahydrocannabinol. No prescription or practitioner’s  order for marihuana, tetrahydrocannabinol, or synthetic equivalents  of marihuana or tetrahydrocannabinol shall be valid, unless the prescription is for a drug that has received  final approval from the United States food and drug administration,  including dronabinol. Any person who violates this subsection:
    1. And has in his possession a controlled substance in the amount set forth in this paragraph is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than twelve (12) months, a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or both. Any person convicted for a third or subsequent offense under this paragraph, including convictions for violations of similar laws in other jurisdictions, shall be imprisoned for a term not more than five (5) years, fined not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), or both. For purposes of this paragraph, the amounts of a controlled substance are as follows:
      1. For a controlled substance in plant form, no more than three (3) ounces;
      2. For a controlled substance in liquid form, no more than three-tenths (3/10) of a gram;
      3. For a controlled substance in powder or crystalline form, no more than three (3) grams;
      4. For a controlled substance in pill or capsule form, no more than three (3) grams;
      5. For a controlled substance in the form of cocaine-based “crack” cocaine, no more than five-tenths (5/10) of a gram;
      6. For a controlled substance known as LSD (Lysergic acid diethylamide), no more than three-tenths (3/10) of a gram.
    2. And has in his possession methamphetamine or a controlled substance classified in Schedule I or II which is a narcotic drug in an amount greater than those set forth in paragraph (c)(i) of this section, is guilty of a felony punishable by imprisonment for not more than seven (7) years, a fine of not more than fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00), or both;
    3. And has in his possession any other controlled substance classified in Schedule I, II or III in an amount greater than set forth in paragraph (c)(i) of this section, is guilty of a felony punishable by imprisonment for not more than five (5) years, a fine of not more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), or both;
    4. And has in his possession a controlled substance classified in Schedule IV in an amount greater than set forth in paragraph (c)(i) of this section, is guilty of a felony punishable by imprisonment for not more than two (2) years, a fine of not more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00), or both;
    5. And has in his possession a controlled substance classified in Schedule V, is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than one (1) year, a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or both.
  4. For purposes of determining the weights to be given the controlled substances under this section, the weights designated in this section shall include the weight of the controlled substance and the weight of any carrier element, cutting agent, diluting agent or any other substance excluding packaging material.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 31; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.31; Laws 1985, ch. 44, § 1; 1995, ch. 61, § 1; 1996, ch. 66, § 1; 1998, ch. 62, § 1; 2004, ch. 87, § 1; 2011, ch. 66, § 1; 2018 ch. 84, § 1, effective July 1, 2018.

The 2004 amendment, effective July 1, 2004, in (c)(i), inserted “including convictions for violations of similar laws in other jurisdictions” preceeding “shall be imprisoned for a term not more than five (5) years.”

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in the introductory language of (c), added the present second sentence.

The 2018 amendment, effective July 1, 2018, in (c), inserted “any drug that has received final approval from the United States food and drug administration, including,” in the second sentence, “unless the prescription is for a drug that has received final approval from the United States food and drug administration, including dronabinol” in the third sentence, and made stylistic changes.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For definition of “this act,” as used in this section, see § 35-7-1002(a)(xxviii).

Conspiracy to deliver controlled substance.—

There was sufficient evidence to support defendant’s conviction for conspiracy to delivery a controlled substance such that a jury could reasonably infer from the facts before it that defendant had an individual connection with, and an appreciable ability to guide the destiny of the over 74 pounds of marijuana found in his compact car packaged in a form consistent with delivery, and producing a strong smell. Mitchell v. State, 2020 WY 142, 476 P.3d 224, 2020 Wyo. LEXIS 166 (Wyo. 2020).

Probable cause existed to issue warrant.

If a deputy unconstitutionally searched defendant’s camper by looking through one window, the search was not invalid because evidence the deputy saw in an uncontested view through another window established probable cause to search the camper by describing the presence of potential drugs and paraphernalia, establishing probable cause to believe possession of a controlled substance was being committed. Workman v. State, 2019 WY 128, 454 P.3d 162, 2019 Wyo. LEXIS 128 (Wyo. 2019); 2019 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (December 18, 2019).

Free exercise of religion. —

Defendant challenging state drug laws on free exercise grounds failed to establish that statutes were anything other than valid and neutral laws of general applicability. Trujillo v. State, 2 P.3d 567, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 108 (Wyo. 2000).

Double Jeopardy was Inapplicable. —

Unpublished decision: State prisoner was not entitled to habeas relief under 28 U.S.C.S. § 2241 because his Double Jeopardy Clause rights were not violated by the refusal of the Wyoming Board of Parole to hold a parole revocation proceeding while he was serving an Arizona sentence after he had absconded while on parole for convictions under Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 35-7-1033 and 35-7-1031. The Double Jeopardy Clause was inapplicable in that the prisoner was serving two separate sentences for convictions in two different states. Vonkrosigk v. Schriro, 384 Fed. Appx. 812, 2010 U.S. App. LEXIS 13412 (10th Cir. Wyo. 2010).

Competency.—

Because defendant did not challenged the trial court's finding that he was competent to enter his Alford plea to felony possession of methamphetamine, any alleged error in the failure to suspend proceedings for a competency evaluation was ultimately inconsequential; defendant's motion to suspend the proceeding did not, by itself, compel the district court to suspend proceedings for a competency evaluation. Marshall v. State, 2016 WY 119, 385 P.3d 304, 2016 Wyo. LEXIS 132 (Wyo. 2016).

Requirements under this section. —

All that is required to constitute the completed crime under this section is knowledge that one is dealing with a controlled substance, coupled with a completed delivery of that contraband. Seymour v. State, 949 P.2d 881, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 156 (Wyo. 1997).

It is unlawful “to … deliver” defines general intent crime. Once a delivery takes place and the crime of delivery is charged, then the offense takes on the characteristics of a general intent crime and an instruction on specific intent is not necessary; the inference thereupon arises that the defendant intended that which resulted. Dorador v. State, 573 P.2d 839, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 257 (Wyo. 1978).

“It is unlawful … to … possess with intent to … deliver” defines specific intent crime. When only the crime of possession with intent to deliver a controlled substance is charged, and there is no physically completed delivery, the offense is a specific intent crime. Dorador v. State, 573 P.2d 839, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 257 (Wyo. 1978).

Fatal variance in information. —

Where defendant who lived in California sold drugs to Wyoming residents in California, to be sold in Wyoming, and was convicted of conspiracy with intent to deliver methamphetamine, but the information alleged that “the conspiratorial agreement occurred in Wyoming or defendant conspired to commit an act beyond the State of Wyoming,” the failure to include an element of the offense charged in the information, that a conspiracy occurred that was intended to have had an effect in Wyoming, was a fatal variance, which a detailed affidavit could not cure. Estrada-Sanchez v. State, 2003 WY 45, 66 P.3d 703, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 56 (Wyo. 2003).

Elements of delivery. —

The court rejected defendant's claim that his mind was unsullied by unlawful intent at the time he delivered what he knew to be marijuana to an undercover officer, because impurity of thought is not an element of the crime of delivery of a controlled substance under this section. Seymour v. State, 949 P.2d 881, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 156 (Wyo. 1997).

This section and § 35-7-1042 (conspiracy) are directed at separate evils. The delivery statute targets the delivery of drugs while the conspiracy statute is directed at prevention of partnerships in crime. Refusal to merge counts under the two statutes would therefore not involve a double jeopardy violation. Dorador v. State, 768 P.2d 1049, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (Wyo. 1989).

This section not lesser included offense of § 6-5-208. —

Taking or passing controlled substances into a jail may be proven without necessarily proving possession of a controlled substance; therefore, possession of a controlled substance, in violation of § 35-7-1031(c), is not necessarily included in the offense of taking or passing a controlled substance into a jail in violation of § 6-5-208.Paramo v. State, 896 P.2d 1342, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 91 (Wyo. 1995).

Evidence sufficient to convict.—

Evidence was sufficient to prove that defendant constructively possessed marijuana found in the trunk of a car in which defendant was a passenger because the smell of raw marijuana in the passenger compartment and the evidence on defendant’s phone demonstrated that defendant knew there was marijuana in the car. Furthermore, the text messages and photographs on the phone and defendant’s own trial testimony proved defendant exercised dominion and control over the marijuana by preparing it for sale and making plans to sell it in Indiana. Pyles v. State, 2020 WY 13, 456 P.3d 926, 2020 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 2020).

Prosecution's burden where defendant charged with delivery. —

Where defendant is charged with delivery of a controlled substance, the burden is on the prosecution to establish, beyond a reasonable doubt, that the defendant “intentionally committed the act.” Dorador v. State, 573 P.2d 839, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 257 (Wyo. 1978).

Basis for sentencing decision. —

Defendant was properly sentenced to 6 to 10 years on the marijuana charge and 3 to 10 years on the methamphetamine charge, to be served consecutively. In light of defendant's failure to object to the presentence investigation report which contained his prior criminal history and in light of his taped statements to police claiming to be a significant drug dealer in the area, the appellate court saw no reliance by the trial court on prosecutorial misconduct in formulating its sentencing decision. Manes v. State, 2004 WY 70, 92 P.3d 289, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 89 (Wyo. 2004), reh'g denied, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 107 (Wyo. July 13, 2004).

Where defendant had adequate opportunity to respond to information offered by the prosecutor at his sentencing hearing that was not in the presentence report, including a drug enforcement agent's testimony that defendant was a well-known local methamphetamine supplier, and where the court relied on such information in rejecting defendant's request for probation or a lesser sentence, defendant's due process rights were not violated because such evidence was reliable, and the sentence was well below the statutory maximum of 20 years set forth in Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 35-7-1031(a)(i). Capellen v. State, 2007 WY 107, 161 P.3d 1076, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 117 (Wyo. 2007).

Prosecutors remarks prejudicial. —

Where the prosecutor's repeated remarks, in the face of sustained objections, were a blatant invitation to the jurors to convict defendant, not on the evidence but because of their fear and disapproval of drug dealers in general, the statements undermine the confidence in the fairness of the verdict and there is a substantial likelihood that defendant may have enjoyed a more favorable verdict had the statements not been made. Gayler v. State, 957 P.2d 855, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 63 (Wyo. 1998).

Evidence sufficient to conclude intent to deliver controlled substances. —

See Patterson v. State, 691 P.2d 253, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 348 (Wyo. 1984), cert. denied, 471 U.S. 1020, 105 S. Ct. 2048, 85 L. Ed. 2d 311, 1985 U.S. LEXIS 2663 (U.S. 1985), overruled, Jones v. State, 902 P.2d 686, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 150 (Wyo. 1995).

Evidence was sufficient to sustain defendant's conviction for possession with intent to deliver methamphetamine where defendant, who had admittedly purchased methamphetamine earlier in the day, was present in a hotel room with two females to “get high” and to “party”. A fanny pack on defendant's person contained, inter alia, a small digital scale containing a white powder residue, eight small baggies with a white powder residue that a forensic chemist later testified was methamphetamine, and 112 unused baggies. Grissom v. State, 2005 WY 132, 121 P.3d 127, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 158 (Wyo. 2005).

Evidence was sufficient to sustain defendant's convictions for possession with intent to deliver methamphetamine, possession of methamphetamine, possession of marijuana, and possession of oxycodone because the drugs were found beneath the car seat in which defendant had been sitting, defendant was under the influence of a controlled substance, he had smoked marijuana earlier in the day, he attempted to evade law enforcement, he changed his story several times, he was carrying a large amount of cash, he refused to identify himself, and he ran when law enforcement attempted to arrest him. An expert witness testified that the scales, packaging material, the quantities of methamphetamine found, and the amount of money defendant was carrying were indicative of someone engaged in drug trafficking. Dettloff v. State, 2007 WY 29, 152 P.3d 376, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (Wyo. 2007).

Where police searched a pickup truck in which defendant was a passenger after receiving a report that defendant was selling drugs out of a truck, and the officer found empty baggies, a scale, and 3.99 grams of methamphetamine; as well as a syringe and a wad of cash in defendant's coat, the evidence was sufficient to convict defendant of possessing a controlled substance with intent to deliver and two counts of possession of a controlled substance in violation of Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 35-7-1031; defendant had exclusive possession of the truck immediately preceding the discovery of the methamphetamine and other drug items. Cureton v. State, 2007 WY 168, 169 P.3d 549, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 180 (Wyo. 2007).

Corroborating evidence not necessary. —

Where the record showed that numerous witnesses admitted to using and selling methamphetamine (meth) which they bought from defendant, defendant's conviction of conspiracy to deliver a controlled substance, methamphetamine, in violation of Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 35-7-1042, 35-7-1031(a)(i), was affirmed because the evidence was sufficient to find that defendant committed the crime alleged in that each of the accomplicetconspirators gave direct testimony at trial, thus, no corroborating evidence was required. Adams v. State, 2003 WY 152, 79 P.3d 526, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 182 (Wyo. 2003).

Conspiracy to deliver controlled substance. —

Testimony of informant that defendant agreed to procure morphine for her, recording of discussions between informant and defendant throughout the course of their transaction, and defendant's statements to investigators that he was on his way to get morphine but changed his mind when he discovered he was being followed constituted sufficient evidence for jury to conclude defendant had an agreement with another person to violate the controlled substances act. Martinez v. State, 943 P.2d 1178, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 111 (Wyo. 1997).

Subject matter jurisdiction over conspiracy. —

The trial court had jurisdiction over a prosecution for conspiracy to deliver a controlled substance, conspiracy to possess a controlled substance with intent to deliver, and conspiracy to possess a controlled substance where the defendant was stopped on a highway in Colorado while en route to deliver marijuana to a coperpetrator in Wyoming, notwithstanding that the conspiracies were not entered into in Wyoming and that the defendant committed no criminal acts in Wyoming, as there was an intent for the conspiracies to have an effect in Wyoming. Marquez v. State, 12 P.3d 711, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 216 (Wyo. 2000).

Constitutionally sufficient showing of probable cause. —

See Guerra v. State, 897 P.2d 447, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 87 (Wyo. 1995).

Trial court did not err in denying defendant's motion to suppress drug evidence, where police officer's continued detention of defendant after he was stopped for speeding was lawful, in that the officer's investigation of potential unauthorized use of rental car was a reasonably sufficient reason to detain him, and defendant voluntarily consented to a search of his luggage. Hembree v. State, 2006 WY 127, 143 P.3d 905, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 133 (Wyo. 2006).

Intent inferred. —

Where there was undisputed circumstantial evidence that a vehicle containing objectionable drugs belonged to defendant and had been in his control immediately prior to his arrest and that he at that time appeared to be under the influence of drugs and had previously been in the possession of them, even suggesting that a mother use them on her three-year-old child, intent under this section may be inferred. Deeter v. State, 500 P.2d 68, 1972 Wyo. LEXIS 271 (Wyo. 1972).

There is no technical definition necessary for intent or for delivery under this section. Sims v. State, 530 P.2d 1176, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 125 (Wyo. 1975).

Word “or” in subsection (a). —

It is significant that the legislature used the disjunctive “or” in subsection (a), thereby indicating that a violation of any of the mentioned prohibitions was a crime. Dorador v. State, 520 P.2d 230, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 192 (Wyo. 1974).

History of the law of specific intent in Wyoming. —

See Stuebgen v. State, 548 P.2d 870, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 181 (Wyo. 1976).

Intent is essential element. —

Where the charge is possession with intent to deliver, it is indisputable that the intent to deliver is just as essential for the prosecution to prove with competent evidence as is the possession. Stuebgen v. State, 548 P.2d 870, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 181 (Wyo. 1976).

Purchaser of narcotics is not accomplice of defendant charged with selling such narcotics. Wheeler v. State, 691 P.2d 599, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 349 (Wyo. 1984).

Reasonableness of detention at traffic stop. —

The reasonableness of the detention is to be measured by whether the police acted diligently under all the circumstances of the case and whether the detention involved delay unnecessary to a legitimate police inquiry. State v. Welch, 873 P.2d 601, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 56 (Wyo. 1994), reh'g denied, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 65 (Wyo. May 25, 1994), reh'g denied, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 67 (Wyo. May 25, 1994).

Even when considering the fact that a patrol car's lights remained flashing and that there were two uniformed officers present, under the totality of the circumstances, a defendant's consent to a second round of questions and subsequent dog sniff search was voluntary because the initial traffic stop was brief, the trooper's conduct was professional, courteous, and non-coercive throughout the length of the entire encounter, and the consents given by the defendant were unhesitant and immediate. Latta v. State, 2009 WY 35, 202 P.3d 1069, 2009 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 2009).

Trooper was permitted to stop defendant's vehicle after observing a cracked windshield, his questions to defendant and the passenger concerning their travel plans were acceptable, and the initial four-minute detention was not unreasonably prolonged. Because the traffic stop did not violate defendant's Fourth Amendment rights, he was not entitled to suppress evidence of methamphetamine and a digital scale seized from the vehicle or evidence of 23 bindles of cocaine seized from his person; defendant was convicted upon a plea of guilty to felony possession of methamphetamine with intent to deliver and felony possession of cocaine with intent to deliver in violation of Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 35-7-1031(a)(i). Lovato v. State, 2010 WY 38, 228 P.3d 55, 2010 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (Wyo. 2010).

Where an informant told a law enforcement agent that he was purchasing methamphetamine from three men staying at a local motel, the agent went to the motel, where he saw one of the men put something into a vehicle and drive away; when the agent saw the driver turn a corner without signaling, the agent was permitted to conduct a traffic stop under Wyo. Const. art. I, § 4. Therefore, the district court denied defendant's motion to suppress evidence of his backpack found in the car containing 20 grams of methamphetamine, 5 grams of cocaine, a digital scale, several razor blades, and packaging material; defendant was properly convicted of two counts of possession of a controlled substance in violation of Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 35-7-1031(c)(ii) and two counts of possession of a controlled substance with intent to deliver in violation of Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 35-7-1031(a)(i). Hernandez v. State, 2010 WY 33, 227 P.3d 315, 2010 Wyo. LEXIS 37 (Wyo. 2010).

In a case in which defendant entered a conditional guilty plea to one count of possession of marijuana, the facts showed defendant knew he was not being detained and, despite being informed he was not required to answer the trooper’s question. The district court properly determined the trooper’s contact with defendant was consensual and accordingly properly denied defendant’s motion to suppress. Kennison v. State, 2018 WY 46, 417 P.3d 146, 2018 Wyo. LEXIS 48 (Wyo. 2018).

A continuous chain of possession is necessary in establishing a proper foundation for the admissibility of a controlled substance. Jackson v. State, 522 P.2d 1356, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 212 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 419 U.S. 1055, 95 S. Ct. 637, 42 L. Ed. 2d 652, 1974 U.S. LEXIS 3665 (U.S. 1974).

Establishing chain of custody. —

Where there is no evidence of any tampering, alteration or other irregularity with regard to drug samples, the chain of custody is adequately established. Le Beau v. State, 589 P.2d 1292, 1979 Wyo. LEXIS 357 (Wyo. 1979).

Defendant lacked standing to challenge the search. —

Defendant failed to carry his burden of showing that he had any possessory interest in the vehicle at the time of the search, thus failing to demonstrate a legitimate expectation of privacy, the consequence of which was a lack of standing by defendant to challenge the search. Putnam v. State, 995 P.2d 632, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 39 (Wyo. 2000).

Where an informant told law enforcement officers that he had recently been in defendant's residence and purchased methamphetamine from defendant the night before, a deputy went to the home of defendant's fiancee's mother and observed a vehicle in the driveway matching the informant's description of the car; during a search of the vehicle, the deputy found drug paraphernalia and more than 20 ounces of marijuana. Defendant lacked standing to challenge the search of his fiancee's vehicle because he had no expectation of privacy in the vehicle; following the denial of his suppression motion, defendant entered a nolo contendere plea to conspiracy to distribute marijuana and possession of marijuana with intent to deliver in violation of this section. Miller v. State, 2009 WY 125, 217 P.3d 793, 2009 Wyo. LEXIS 137 (Wyo. 2009).

Reasonable suspicion and probable cause. —

There was a reasonable, articulable suspicion of illegal activity which justified defendant's detention and frisk search, and the arrest of defendant was supported by probable cause based on the location of the drugs and defendant's access and control over that location. Putnam v. State, 995 P.2d 632, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 39 (Wyo. 2000).

Motion to suppress was properly denied because a search did not violate the defendants' rights under the U.S. Const. amend. IV or under Wyo. Const. art. I, § 4; a dog sniff was justified by a reasonably articulable suspicion of illegal activity, and the dog's alert provided the officer with probable cause to search the trunk. Yoeuth v. State, 2009 WY 61, 206 P.3d 1278, 2009 Wyo. LEXIS 59 (Wyo. 2009).

Defendant's constitutional rights were not violated when an officer detained defendant for a canine drug sniff because a past-due car rental agreement, defendant's unusual travel plans, the presence of oven cooking bags on the front passenger seat of defendant's vehicle, and defendant's unusual nervousness justified the officer's suspicion that defendant was engaging in illegal activities; hence, defendant's conviction for possession with intent to deliver marijuana, in violation of Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 35-7-1031(a)(ii), was proper. Sutton v. State, 2009 WY 148, 220 P.3d 784, 2009 Wyo. LEXIS 166 (Wyo. 2009).

Trailer ball mounted in a place that partially obstructed a license plate from an officer's view was a traffic violation that gave the officer probable cause to conduct a traffic stop; therefore, defendant was not entitled to suppress evidence of marijuana and a pipe he surrendered to the officer during the stop. Defendant was properly convicted on a conditional guilty plea to possession of a controlled substance in violation of this section. Parks v. State, 2011 WY 19, 247 P.3d 857, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 2011).

Probable cause existed to issue warrant. —

Probable cause existed to issue search warrant where the issuing judge learned from the affidavit of a trained and experienced law enforcement officer that juvenile suspects in a criminal case had, against their penal interests, admitted an attempt to steal marijuana from defendant, the juveniles had learned of the marijuana grow operation from defendant's son, they identified the location of the operation, power company records indicated an inordinate use of electricity on defendant's property consistent with a grow operation, and defendant's criminal history revealed previous controlled substance convictions, including ones for illegal manufacture of marijuana. Kitzke v. State, 2002 WY 147, 55 P.3d 696, 2002 Wyo. LEXIS 161 (Wyo. 2002).

Warrantless search proper. —

It was permissible to search without a warrant based upon reasonable cause to belief that the evidence of the theft could be found in defendant's vehicle. Callaway v. State, 954 P.2d 1365, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (Wyo. 1998).

In a prosecution for felony possession of a controlled substance, the trial court properly denied the defendant's motion to suppress evidence seized from her vehicle after her arrest on an outstanding traffic warrant since: (1) a search of the passenger compartment of her vehicle incident to that arrest was appropriate under federal law, (2) the defendant failed to raise a state constitutional issue below, and (3) it was questionable whether a recent Wyoming supreme court opinion could be retrospectively applied to the search at issue. Bailey v. State, 12 P.3d 173, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 209 (Wyo. 2000).

Methamphetamine and marijuana discovered during a vehicle search were improperly suppressed; an external dog sniff provided probable cause to believe that the vehicle contained contraband, and there was no need to show exigent circumstances in order to justify the warrantless search. State v. Williams, 2004 WY 53, 90 P.3d 85, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 64 (Wyo. 2004).

Where officers received an urgent, garbled radio transmission at 4:30 a.m. from defendant's wife, an emergency medical technician (EMT), and went to their home to locate the EMT where they found a system for growing mushrooms in a bedroom, the search of the home was constitutional because the emergency assistance exception applied; the officers were acting reasonably when they investigated the possible emergency and properly limited their efforts to determining whether anyone was in need of assistance rather than investigating a crime. Moulton v. State, 2006 WY 152, 148 P.3d 38, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 169 (Wyo. 2006).

Where unlawful drugs were found in premises not occupied exclusively by the defendant, and nothing more is shown, the evidence is circumstantial and insufficient because it does not exclude every reasonable hypothesis except that of guilt. Neuroth v. State, 524 P.2d 590, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 220 (Wyo. 1974).

Labeling defendant as “pusher.” —

If testimony of narcotic offenses on other occasions have no probative value except to show a propensity on the part of the defendant to commit that kind of crime, the labeling of a defendant who was charged with possession of marihuana with intent to deliver as a “pusher” is much more than merely testifying to an earlier transaction involving narcotics, as the label implies that the defendant was a professional seller of narcotics, engaged in that unsavory occupation for a substantial period of time. Dorador v. State, 520 P.2d 230, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 192 (Wyo. 1974).

Where defense of entrapment is possibility. —

In a prosecution for crimes of possession with intent to deliver marihuana and delivery of marihuana, where the defense of entrapment was a possibility, it was prejudicial error for the state to deny permission to the accused to interview the individual who had contacted the accused and arranged for and was present at the sales transaction, who was the principal participating witness at trial and who, at the time of the trial, had been charged with possession of marihuana and hoped to be benefited by cooperating with the attorney general's office but who had been referred to by the prosecuting attorney as merely an informer. Jackson v. State, 522 P.2d 1286, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 211 (Wyo. 1974), commented on in 10 Land & Water L. Rev. 293 (1975).

Investigatory drug snares immunized. —

The acquisition, use and sale for investigatory purposes, without registration, of marijuana did not violate defendant's right to due process where the technical violations at issue were implicitly immunized under § 35-7-1043 as legitimate investigatory drug snares. Rivera v. State, 846 P.2d 1, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 1993).

Proof necessary to convict for possession of illicit drugs. —

In order to convict for possession of illicit drugs, the prosecution must establish that the accused either individually or jointly with another exercised dominion and control over the substance, had knowledge of its presence and had knowledge that the substance was a controlled substance; constructive possession is all that is necessary and such may be proved by circumstantial evidence linking together a series of facts. Wise v. State, 654 P.2d 116, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 402 (Wyo. 1982).

“Possession” of substance in physical custody of another. —

If a defendant is sufficiently associated with the persons having physical custody of a controlled substance so that he is able, without difficulty, to cause the drug to be produced for a customer, he can be found by a jury to have dominion and control over the drug and, therefore, possession. Wise v. State, 654 P.2d 116, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 402 (Wyo. 1982).

A person who, in one transaction, possesses with intent to deliver and delivers a controlled substance commits a single violation of the statute and should incur only one punishment. Dorador v. State, 520 P.2d 230, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 192 (Wyo. 1974).

If a person is charged with delivery of a controlled substance and possession of the same substance with intent to deliver, the latter is embraced in the former. Boyd v. State, 528 P.2d 287, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 247 (Wyo. 1974), cert. denied, 423 U.S. 871, 96 S. Ct. 137, 46 L. Ed. 2d 102, 1975 U.S. LEXIS 2819 (U.S. 1975).

Possession of a controlled substance with intent to deliver and unlawful delivery of a controlled substance are under this section separate and distinct. Jackson v. State, 522 P.2d 1356, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 212 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 419 U.S. 1055, 95 S. Ct. 637, 42 L. Ed. 2d 652, 1974 U.S. LEXIS 3665 (U.S. 1974).

Possession and attempted possession may be charged and tried together. —

It was proper for the indictment to charge possession of a controlled substance with intent to deliver and attempted possession of a controlled substance with intent to deliver, and it was also proper that both alleged violations be tried in one proceeding because they were of similar character and based on the same act or transaction or, at the very least, on two or more acts or transactions connected together or constituting part of a common scheme or plan. Jerskey v. State, 546 P.2d 173, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 170 (Wyo. 1976). See Rule 11, W.R. Cr. P.

Prescription justifying lawful possession. —

In a prosecution for possession of a controlled substance in violation of subsection (c), it is not necessary for the state to prove that the defendant did not have a prescription justifying lawful possession; the burden of that exception is on the defendant. Pool v. State, 2001 WY 8, 17 P.3d 1285, 2001 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 2001).

Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 35-7-1031(c) did not exempt defendant from criminal liability even if defendant obtained a legitimate medical marijuana exception under Colorado law; because Colorado law did not allow a physician to prescribe marijuana possession, a Colorado registry card for the use of medical marijuana was irrelevant to criminal proceedings. Burns v. State, 2011 WY 5, 246 P.3d 283, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 2011), reh'g denied, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 37 (Wyo. Feb. 23, 2011).

Because a California physician's recommendation to use marijuana for medical purposes was not a valid prescription or medical practitioner's order within the meaning of Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 35-7-1031(c) and was not a valid defense to the charge of felony possession of marijuana under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 35-7-1031(c)(iii), evidence of a medical marijuana card from a California physician was properly excluded as irrelevant under Wyo. R. Evid. 401, 402; thus, the district court did not deny him his constitutional right under Wyo. Const. art. 1, § 10 to present a defense. Bruyette v. State, 2011 WY 99, 253 P.3d 512, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 101 (Wyo. 2011).

Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 35-7-1031(c) did not exempt defendant from criminal liability even if defendant obtained a legitimate medical marijuana exception under Colorado law; because Colorado law did not allow a physician to prescribe marijuana possession, a Colorado registry card for the use of medical marijuana was irrelevant to criminal proceedings. Burns v. State, 2011 WY 5, 246 P.3d 283, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 2011), reh'g denied, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 37 (Wyo. Feb. 23, 2011).

“Or any other substance excluding packaging material.” —

Subsection (d) was not unconstitutionally vague as applied to convict defendant of felony possession of a controlled substance, since the phrase “or any other substance excluding packaging material” is broad enough to have included the weight of water containing methamphetamine found in his possession. Smith v. State, 964 P.2d 421, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 126 (Wyo. 1998).

Conviction may only be on one count. —

Where the indictment charged defendant with possession of a controlled substance with intent to deliver and attempted possession of a controlled substance with intent to deliver, even though both counts could be brought under the same complaint (both counts could be tried at the same time, the same witnesses could testify in the proof of each charge insofar as their testimony was relevant, material and competent, or otherwise admissible, and the same evidence could be received to support each count), the defendant could not be convicted and sentenced to prison for more than one offense. There was but one transaction, one common scheme or plan, and, because one offense was merged with another, the convictions may not be stacked because the result would be to have twice placed the defendant in jeopardy in that he would have received multiple punishment for the same offense at one trial. Jerskey v. State, 546 P.2d 173, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 170 (Wyo. 1976).

Provisions governing marijuana-related offenses. —

Because marijuana is a schedule I controlled substance under § 35-7-1014(d)(xiii) but is not a “narcotic drug,” as that term is defined by § 35-7-1002(a)(xv), offenses involving marijuana are governed by subsection (a)(ii) rather than subsection (a)(i). Eaton v. State, 660 P.2d 803, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 294 (Wyo. 1983).

Dispensing of controlled substance by pharmacist outside of statutory authority. —

See Dover v. State, 664 P.2d 536, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 334 (Wyo. 1983).

Where portion of substance sold, and rest remains in possession, two offenses charged. —

Where the accused sells the same substance he is charged with possessing, clearly the two offenses must be said to have merged. However, where a designated portion of a controlled substance is sold and the rest, or a different controlled substance, remains in the defendant's possession, both offenses of possession with intent to deliver, and delivery, may be charged. State v. Carter, 714 P.2d 1217, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 487 (Wyo. 1986).

Merger of distinct offenses. —

In certain situations the violation of a charged offense separate and distinct from another with respect to statutory definition is necessarily embraced in and merged in the other. Jackson v. State, 522 P.2d 1356, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 212 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 419 U.S. 1055, 95 S. Ct. 637, 42 L. Ed. 2d 652, 1974 U.S. LEXIS 3665 (U.S. 1974).

Evidence obtained as result of canine sniff. —

The district court erred in suppressing evidence obtained as a result of the “canine sniff” of the respondents' vehicle; the initial stop was lawful and was followed by a minimally intrusive detention of the vehicle and the respondents on a reasonably articulable suspicion premised upon objective facts indicating that the respondents' vehicle contained contraband. State v. Welch, 873 P.2d 601, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 56 (Wyo. 1994), reh'g denied, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 65 (Wyo. May 25, 1994), reh'g denied, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 67 (Wyo. May 25, 1994).

No suppression of drug evidence. —

In defendant's criminal prosecution for possession of marijuana with intent to deliver and possession of more than three ounces of marijuana, the district court properly denied his motion to suppress evidence of a plastic bag containing eight ounces of marijuana seized during the search of his disabled vehicle. Defendant was properly convicted on his conditional pleas to the felony charge of possession of more than three ounces of marijuana and a misdemeanor charge of possession of marijuana. Morgan v. State, 2004 WY 95, 95 P.3d 802, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 121 (Wyo. 2004).

Where an informant told law enforcement officers that he had recently been in defendant's residence and purchased methamphetamine from defendant the night before, exigent circumstances justified the officers' warrantless entry into the residence to ensure that there was no one inside who might destroy evidence or threaten officer safety; after a two-minute sweep, the officers left the residence and waited outside for the search warrant. Defendant was not entitled to suppress evidence of marijuana, methamphetamine, and psilocybin mushrooms seized during the execution of the warrant; defendant was convicted of felony possession of marijuana with intent to deliver, misdemeanor possession of psilocybin, and misdemeanor possession of methamphetamine in violation of this section. Miller v. State, 2009 WY 125, 217 P.3d 793, 2009 Wyo. LEXIS 137 (Wyo. 2009).

No abuse of discretion in receiving tape recording made during sale of cocaine into evidence, nor in permitting jurors to have transcripts of tape recording. Crisp v. State, 944 P.2d 1165, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 124 (Wyo. 1997).

Evidence held sufficient. — See Simmons v. State, 687 P.2d 255, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 345 (Wyo. 1984); Pisano v. State, 828 P.2d 666, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 39 (Wyo. 1992).

—

Evidence was sufficient to support defendant’s conviction of felony possession of methamphetamine in a liquid form because the evidence established that the Wyoming State Crime Lab tested a pourable liquid obtained from defendant’s water pipe and that pourable liquid tested positive for methamphetamine. Mathewson v. State, 2019 WY 36, 438 P.3d 189, 2019 Wyo. LEXIS 36 (Wyo. 2019).

Evidence supported count of delivery. —

Evidence did not reasonably support the conclusion that defendant was guilty of possession, but not delivery, of a controlled substance. Pearson v. State, 12 P.3d 686, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 213 (Wyo. 2000), reh'g denied, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 222 (Wyo. Nov. 21, 2000), dismissed, 2003 WY 71, 70 P.3d 235, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 87 (Wyo. 2003).

Evidence was sufficient to sustain a conviction for delivering a controlled substance where defendant sold methamphetamine out of an accomplice's motel room with her knowledge, the accomplice negotiated for the informant to buy methamphetamine from defendant at least partially with defendant's knowledge, and defendant delivered to the informant the quantity of methamphetamine agreed to between the informant and the accomplice. In addition, the informant testified that it was defendant who sold her the drugs. Leyo v. State, 2005 WY 92, 116 P.3d 1113, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 109 (Wyo. 2005).

Where police officers responded to a report that the odor of burning marijuana was emanating from an apartment where minors were present, defendant retrieved from her bedroom a wooden box containing a small amount of marijuana and other paraphernalia. The corporal testified that three juveniles admitted that they had smoked marijuana and defendant admitted that she supplied the drugs; the evidence was sufficient to support defendant's conviction for three felony counts of delivery of a controlled substance to a minor in violation of this section. Anderson v. State, 2009 WY 119, 216 P.3d 1143, 2009 Wyo. LEXIS 130 (Wyo. 2009).

Evidence sufficient to convict. —

Evidence which included the testimony of an undercover agent that defendant had sold and delivered to him controlled substances was sufficient to convict defendant under this section notwithstanding defendant's testimony alleging entrapment. Montez v. State, 527 P.2d 1330, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 246 (Wyo. 1974).

Where defendant was in his car at the time the pills were found and had been in the vehicle during at least portions of the period in which he contended others may have placed the pills there, the evidence was sufficient to sustain defendant's conviction of possessing a controlled substance. Valerio v. State, 527 P.2d 154, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 239 (Wyo. 1974).

Evidence that included bookkeeping entries recording the defendant's drug transactions with a witness and the defendant's admission that he had been smoking marijuana at the time of arrest was sufficient to convict the defendant for possession of marijuana. Urrutia v. State, 924 P.2d 965, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 136 (Wyo. 1996).

There was sufficient circumstantial evidence to establish a defendant's intent to deliver marijuana where the state's key witness testified that the defendant told him that he could “get rid of a lot” of drugs for him and that the defendant left the witness's apartment with drugs and returned later with money and no drugs. Urrutia v. State, 924 P.2d 965, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 136 (Wyo. 1996).

Although defendant argued that there was insufficient evidence to sustain his conviction for possession of marijuana with intent to deliver because the State failed to prove beyond a reasonable doubt essential elements of the crime, the appellate court was compelled to conclude that the evidence was sufficient. The foregoing was especially true in light of defendant's admission that he had sold marijuana in the past to supplement his income, and a search of defendant's home revealed the $100 bill an agent had used to purchase marijuana, which was inadvertently returned to the defendant's wife, as well as a box of plastic baggies, weighing scales, a marijuana sifter, and suspected marijuana and methamphetamine. Pacheco v. State, 2004 WY 160, 102 P.3d 887, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 207 (Wyo. 2004).

Defendant was properly convicted of conspiracy to possess methamphetamine with the intent to deliver. The agreement of the conspiracy, to regain possession of the half pound of commercial methamphetamine in an accomplice's bag so that the accomplice could sell the methamphetamine, could be reasonably inferred from the communication between the accomplices and defendant regarding what occurred vis a vis the informant. The defendant's intentional or active participation in the conspiracy could reasonably be inferred from the relationship between the defendant and accomplices, the communication between them regarding what occurred vis a vis the informant, the defendant's role in the ensuing discussions at the defendant's residence and in his vehicle, the particular statements attributed to the defendant during these discussions, and the defendant's conduct at his residence and upon leaving the residence. The requisite intent could reasonably be inferred from the foregoing and additional evidence concerning the accomplice's stated purpose in regaining possession of the methamphetamine, the testimony regarding the significance of the quantity of the methamphetamine involved, and the testimony regarding the manner in which the methamphetamine was packaged. Ekholm v. State, 2004 WY 159, 102 P.3d 201, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 206 (Wyo. 2004).

Evidence was sufficient to sustain defendant's conviction for possession of marijuana because, notwithstanding the fact that the baggy contained “stems and seed,” the evidence clearly established that the baggy also contained marijuana leaf, which fell directly within the definition of “marijuana.” Leyva v. State, 2005 WY 22, 106 P.3d 873, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 24 (Wyo. 2005).

Evidence was sufficient for the jury to have found beyond a reasonable doubt that defendant possessed a controlled substance, because (1) methamphetamine was discovered inches away from defendant after he made several unusual movements with his leg; (2) the baggie containing the methamphetamine was warm to the touch; and (3) defendant was under arrest and was aware he would be taken to jail giving him motive to dispose of the substance. Doherty v. State, 2006 WY 39, 131 P.3d 963, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 42 (Wyo. 2006).

Evidence was sufficient to convict defendant of three counts of possession with intent to deliver a controlled substance, based on finding defendant had constructive possession of the drugs on the date of the search, as he had a key to the apartment and had unfettered access to the apartment, defendant's friend testified that defendant sent him the key to the apartment so that he could access the apartment, and the friend testified about defendant's behavior shortly after the search and defendant's specific knowledge regarding the variety and location of the drugs in the apartment. Taylor v. State, 2011 WY 18, 246 P.3d 596, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 2011).

State met its burden when it proved defendant knowingly or intentionally possessed a controlled substance. A police officer's testimony, along with the formal tests proving the substance to be methamphetamine, supplied sufficient evidence that defendant was in possession of a controlled substance. Daley v. State, 2016 WY 22, 368 P.3d 291, 2016 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 2016).

Evidence was sufficient to support defendant’s conviction of constructively possessing a controlled substance, given that the drugs were found in a backpack that belonged to defendant, who placed it in the vehicle, the owner of the vehicle testified that he never touched the backpack, and the jury was free to reject defendant’s disavowal of any knowledge of the drugs. Lemley v. State, 2016 WY 65, 375 P.3d 760, 2016 Wyo. LEXIS 74 (Wyo. 2016).
