Evidence was sufficient to convict defendant of felony possession of methamphetamine as defendant told law enforcement that he ran from them because he had methamphetamine in his pocket; and an agent testified that the methamphetamine weighed 4.36 grams. Childers v. State, 2021 WY 93, 493 P.3d 168, 2021 Wyo. LEXIS 102 (Wyo. 2021).

Evidence was sufficient to support defendant's convictions of possession with intent to deliver and possession of methamphetamine because: (1) a witness testified that defendant loaded a pipe with methamphetamine, hand it to her, and she smoked it; (2) the witness identified an exhibit as a glass pipe that she and defendant had purchased a few weeks before his arrest; (3) another witness testified that the night before defendant's arrest, she helped him put drug paraphernalia in bags and that she and defendant smoked methamphetamine that defendant provided; (4) police officers found a black fanny pack in defendant's residence that contained several bags of U.S. currency, metal tins containing bags of methamphetamine and marijuana, a propane lighter, a glass pipe, and 2.36 grams of methamphetamine; (5) officers found drug paraphernalia in two bags on defendant's residence; and (6) the officers found bags containing methamphetamine and methamphetamine residue in defendant's storage shed. Bromley v. State, 2007 WY 20, 150 P.3d 1202, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 2007).

Conviction under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 35-7-1031(a) for possessing marijuana, as defined by Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 35-7-1002(a)(xiv), with intent to distribute was supported by sufficient circumstantial evidence, including the marijuana stems and seeds, scale, pipes and bongs containing marijuana residue, baggies used to package marijuana, and $ 345 in cash found near his computer desk in his living room; his girlfriend's testimony that she saw him use and sell marijuana; the testimony of the girlfriend's brother that he purchased marijuana from and smoked it with defendant; defendant's admission to a detective that he possessed, used, and sold marijuana; and his testimony that the seeds and stems were what was left after he had finished smoking the pot just before he was arrested. Shumaker v. State, 2007 WY 143, 167 P.3d 11, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 2007).

Evidence was sufficient to convict defendant of three counts of possession with intent to deliver a controlled substance because 1) defendant had dominion and control over the drugs as his girlfriend testified that the drugs belonged to him, and that he placed them in the apartment; 2) the girlfriend testified that defendant frequently asked her to give packages of the drugs to people defendant sent to the apartment; 3) defendant had a key to the apartment where the drugs were found and many of defendant's personal items were discovered in the apartment, including clothes, shoes, hats, and his wallet; 4) defendant was aware of the type and location of the drugs in the apartment as defendant's friend testified that, a few days after the search, defendant told him there was methamphetamine in the apartment in the pantry on the top shelf to the right and, when the police searched the apartment, they found methamphetamine in that very spot; 5) the fact that the drugs were concealed in bags and placed in hiding places indicated that defendant knew he was bringing illegal controlled substances into the apartment and needed to conceal them; and 6) defendant had constructive possession of the drugs on the date of the search as he had a key to the apartment since 2007 and had unfettered access to the apartment, defendant's friend testified that defendant sent him the key to the apartment after October 30, 2008, so that he could access the apartment, and the friend testified about defendant's behavior shortly after the search and defendant's specific knowledge regarding the variety and location of the drugs in the apartment. Taylor v. State, 2011 WY 18, 246 P.3d 596, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 2011).

Insufficient evidence to convict.

In a prosecution of defendant for felony possession of marijuana, the evidence was insufficient to support a conviction of constructive felony possession. There was no evidence indicating that defendant arranged any of the interactions, took any part in any negotiations, or made any attempt at all to associate himself with or influence the destiny of the marijuana. Regan v. State, 2015 WY 62, 350 P.3d 702, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 70 (Wyo. 2015).

Lay witness testimony regarding defendant's intoxication. —

In a case where defendant asserted a defense of self-induced intoxication to the offense of unlawful possession with intent to deliver under this section, the testimony of two bartenders, including their observations of defendant and specifically that he was not too intoxicated to be served alcohol, was helpful to the fact-finder's determination of whether defendant had the requisite intent to commit the crime; thus, the trial court did not err in admitting their testimony. Mickelson v. State, 2012 WY 137, 287 P.3d 750, 2012 Wyo. LEXIS 142 (Wyo. 2012).

Evidence insufficient to meet test of possession. —

Absent evidence to show the nature of the contents of an additional eight paper “decks” which defendant had but did not deliver, the charge of possession of a controlled substance with intent to deliver as relates to this material does not meet the test of possession beyond a reasonable doubt. Jackson v. State, 522 P.2d 1356, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 212 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 419 U.S. 1055, 95 S. Ct. 637, 42 L. Ed. 2d 652, 1974 U.S. LEXIS 3665 (U.S. 1974).

Mere presence of a person in the vehicle belonging to another where the contraband was discovered did not amount to possession nor was it adequate to establish probable cause for believing the crime in question had been or was being committed by that person. Rodarte v. Riverton, 552 P.2d 1245, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 208 (Wyo. 1976).

Sufficient foundation was laid for admission of plastic evidence bag containing cocaine for prosecution under this section. Jackson v. State, 522 P.2d 1356, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 212 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 419 U.S. 1055, 95 S. Ct. 637, 42 L. Ed. 2d 652, 1974 U.S. LEXIS 3665 (U.S. 1974).

When cross-examination question on heroin sale not prejudicial. —

A question on cross-examination as to a statement that the defendant had sold heroin did not conclusively create an inference, warranting a mistrial, that defendant was a heroin dealer where the question was based upon a reference “about this incident,” and an instruction given by the court clarified the phrase and explained the foundation upon which the question rested and the reason the question had been asked. Palato v. State, 591 P.2d 891, 1979 Wyo. LEXIS 378 (Wyo. 1979).

Judge may poll jurors to determine their intent, nullify verdict on lesser offense. —

There was no error in the trial judge — following instructions on delivering a controlled substance and possession of a controlled substance, and the jury finding the defendant guilty of both offenses — polling the panel and determining its true intent, sentencing the defendant for delivery of a controlled substance and nullifying the jury's verdict on the lesser offense. Johnson v. State, 695 P.2d 638, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 446 (Wyo. 1985), cert. denied, 491 U.S. 908, 109 S. Ct. 3195, 105 L. Ed. 2d 703, 1989 U.S. LEXIS 3045 (U.S. 1989).

Misdemeanor possession a lesser-included offense of felony possession. —

Trial court erred in failing to give lesser-included offense instruction, since jury rationally could have concluded that defendant possessed 0.3 grams or less of methamphetamine, making her guilty of misdemeanor possession, not felony possession, and misdemeanor possession was a lesser-included offense of felony possession. Houghton v. State, 6 P.3d 643, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 128 (Wyo. 2000).

Jury instructions. —

There is no requirement that possession of the controlled substance in question by the defendant must be exclusive, and jury instruction in prosecution for possession was not in error because it failed to contain a requirement of exclusive possession. Valerio v. State, 527 P.2d 154, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 239 (Wyo. 1974).

A specific intent instruction which permitted the jury to accept without proof that defendants intended to deliver the marijuana because they performed “an act which it is known will produce a particular result, [and] it is from our common experience presumed to have anticipated that result and to have intended it” was erroneous. Stuebgen v. State, 548 P.2d 870, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 181 (Wyo. 1976).

In connection with defendant’s trial for constructive possession of a controlled substance, the trial court did not err in refusing to give defendant’s proposed instruction, as it was unnecessary given that the instructions given by the trial court correctly explained the law to the jury; the proposed instruction did little more than state the commonsense principle that to knowingly possess a controlled substance, you must know you have it and what it is. Lemley v. State, 2016 WY 65, 375 P.3d 760, 2016 Wyo. LEXIS 74 (Wyo. 2016).

Jury instruction regarding definition of marijuana. —

In a prosecution for illegal possession of marijuana, the court's definition of “marijuana” in the jury instructions was sufficient where the evidence presented at trial showed that the baggy contained marijuana leaf and thus fell within the definition of marijuana, and counsel inferred and presented evidence that the baggy contained “seeds and stems” and later argued to the jury that it was illogical for a person to attempt to sell a “bag of seeds and stems.” Leyva v. State, 2005 WY 22, 106 P.3d 873, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 24 (Wyo. 2005).

Prior convictions under earlier statutory version may be used to enhance. —

The legislative intent is clear that prior convictions under the earlier version of subsection (c) of this section may be used to enhance the penalty under its current version. Demeulenaere v. State, 995 P.2d 132, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 2000).

Incarceration justified for defendant selling drugs to youth and not accepting responsibility. —

Where the prosecutor and investigation report recommended incarceration, and there was testimony indicating that defendant had been selling drugs to young people and that he was unwilling to accept responsibility for his acts, the court did not abuse its discretion in sentencing defendant to incarceration. Yates v. State, 723 P.2d 37, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 592 (Wyo. 1986).

In a prosecution for possession of cocaine with intent to deliver, the trial court erred in refusing to give a lesser-included offense instruction on possession of a controlled substance where the trial court was put on notice that a lesser-included offense instruction was being requested; possession of a controlled substance is a lesser-included offense of possession with intent to deliver; and the evidence cited by defendant, if believed, negated the inference of intent to sell. Thomas v. State, 2003 WY 53, 67 P.3d 1199, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 65 (Wyo. 2003).

Charge dismissed with prejudice as discovery sanction. —

Even though district court had the authority, under Wyo. R. Crim. P. 16(d)(2), to dismiss a criminal drug charge against defendant with prejudice for the State's failure to produce a police report containing defendant's statement, it abused its discretion by doing so without conducting the appropriate inquiry to determine whether the sanction was justified. The district court made no findings as to the reasons why the State did not produce the report, it made no findings about the prejudice that would be suffered by defendant if the charge was not dismissed with prejudice, and it did not discuss whether prejudice could be cured by a less severe sanction such as a continuance. State v. Naple, 2006 WY 125, 143 P.3d 358, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 128 (Wyo. 2006).

Separate sentences proper. —

Separate sentences for possession and possession with intent to deliver were proper because the evidence presented at trial showed that defendant possessed methamphetamine both for his own use and for delivery to others. The evidence also showed that agents found separate packages of methamphetamine in different quantities in several locations in and around defendant's residence. Bromley v. State, 2007 WY 20, 150 P.3d 1202, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 2007).

Motion to dismiss was properly denied. —

Trial court properly denied defendant's motion to dismiss a charge of felony possession of a controlled substance pursuant to the enhancement provisions of Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 35-7-1031(c)(i) because defendant's waiver of the right to counsel in a prior misdemeanor proceeding was knowing and intelligent; the advisements given in the prior proceeding complied with Wyo. R. Crim. P. 11(b). Craft v. State, 2011 WY 142, 262 P.3d 1253, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 148 (Wyo. 2011).

Applied in

Janski v. State, 538 P.2d 271, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 152 (Wyo. 1975); Jackson v. State, 533 P.2d 1, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 135 (Wyo. 1975); Hicklin v. State, 535 P.2d 743, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 142, 79 A.L.R.3d 1050 (Wyo. 1975); Jasch v. State, 563 P.2d 1327, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 247 (Wyo. 1977); Clenin v. State, 573 P.2d 844, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 258 (Wyo. 1978); Ehrenborg v. State, 639 P.2d 886, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 287 (Wyo. 1982); Ostrowski v. State, 665 P.2d 471, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 332 (Wyo. 1983); Montez v. State, 670 P.2d 694, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 371 (Wyo. 1983); Tompkins v. State, 705 P.2d 836, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 538 (Wyo. 1985).; Perry v. State, 927 P.2d 1158, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 163 (Wyo. 1996); Beintema v. State, 936 P.2d 1221, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 67 (Wyo. 1997); Meek v. State, 2002 WY 1, 37 P.3d 1279, 2002 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (Wyo. 2002); Rideout v. State, 2005 WY 141, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 167, 122 P.3d 201 (2005); Allgier v. State, 2015 WY 137, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 154 (Oct. 23, 2015).

Quoted in

White v. Board of Trustees, 648 P.2d 528, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 361 (Wyo. 1982); Wright v. State, 670 P.2d 1090, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 373 (Wyo. 1983); Chapman v. State, 728 P.2d 631 (Wyo. 1986); Gist v. State, 737 P.2d 336, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 450 (Wyo. 1987); Hennigan v. State, 746 P.2d 360, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 536 (Wyo. 1987); Jandro v. State, 781 P.2d 512, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 212 (Wyo. 1989); Goettl v. State, 842 P.2d 549, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 174 (Wyo. 1992); Gilliam v. State, 890 P.2d 1104, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 1995); Contreras v. State, 7 P.3d 917, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 166 (Wyo. 2000); Pierce v. State, 2007 WY 182, 171 P.3d 525, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 194 (Nov. 15, 2007); Smallfoot v. State, 2012 WY 39, 272 P.3d 314, 2012 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (Mar. 16, 2012); Majors v. State, 2011 WY 63, 252 P.3d 435, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 65 (Apr. 13, 2011); Bowlsby v. State, 2013 WY 72, 302 P.3d 913, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 76 (Jun 12, 2013); Bowlsby v. State, 2013 WY 72, 302 P.3d 913, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 76 (Jun 12, 2013); Marshall v. State, 2014 WY 168, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 191 (Dec. 23, 2014).

Stated in

Dorador v. State, 711 P.2d 417, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 626 (Wyo. 1985); Capshaw v. State, 714 P.2d 349, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 496 (Wyo. 1986); Robinson v. State, 716 P.2d 364, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 515 (Wyo. 1986); Lee v. State, 743 P.2d 296, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 513 (Wyo. 1987).

Cited in

Escobedo v. State, 580 P.2d 655, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 207 (Wyo. 1978); Roby v. State, 587 P.2d 641, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 251 (Wyo. 1978); Hernandez v. State, 587 P.2d 1094, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 250 (Wyo. 1978); Apodaca v. State, 627 P.2d 1023, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 351 (Wyo. 1981); Siegert v. State, 634 P.2d 323, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 373 (Wyo. 1981); State v. Zespy, 723 P.2d 564, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 600 (Wyo. 1986); Brown v. State, 738 P.2d 1092, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 461 (Wyo. 1987); Burke v. State, 746 P.2d 852, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 550 (Wyo. 1987); Mower v. State, 750 P.2d 679, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (Wyo. 1988); Gist v. State, 766 P.2d 1149, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 178 (Wyo. 1988); Billis v. State, 800 P.2d 401, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 119 (Wyo. 1990); Hudson v. State, 800 P.2d 471, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 172 (Wyo. 1990); Kruzich v. State, 800 P.2d 489, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 112 (Wyo. 1990); Fortner v. State, 843 P.2d 1139, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 177 (Wyo. 1992); Mondello v. State, 843 P.2d 1152, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 192 (Wyo. 1992); Wells v. State, 846 P.2d 589, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 203 (Wyo. 1992); Saldana v. State, 846 P.2d 604, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1993); Pino v. State, 849 P.2d 716, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 62 (Wyo. 1993); Lobatos v. State, 875 P.2d 716, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 68 (Wyo. 1994); Vargas-Rocha v. State, 891 P.2d 763, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 37 (Wyo. 1995); Nava v. State, 904 P.2d 364, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 192 (Wyo. 1995); Kaldwell v. State, 908 P.2d 987, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 234 (Wyo. 1995); Medrano v. State, 914 P.2d 804, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 51 (Wyo. 1996); Miller v. State, 942 P.2d 1108, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 105 (Wyo. 1997); DCI. Merkison v. State, 996 P.2d 1138, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 24 (Wyo. 2000); Delacruz v. State, 10 P.3d 1131, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 191 (Wyo. 2000); Capshaw v. State, 11 P.3d 905, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 197 (Wyo. 2000); Oler v. United States, 2001 WY 9, 17 P.3d 27, 2001 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 2001); Nixon v. State, 2001 WY 15, 18 P.3d 631, 2001 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (Wyo. 2001); Asch v. State, 2003 WY 18, 62 P.3d 945, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 2003); Dysthe v. State, 2003 WY 20, 63 P.3d 875, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (Wyo. 2003); Meadows v. State, 2003 WY 37, 65 P.3d 33, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (Wyo. 2003); Sweets v. State, 2003 WY 64, 69 P.3d 404, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 81 (Wyo. 2003); Fender v. State, 2003 WY 96, 74 P.3d 1220, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 117 (Wyo. 2003); Brown v. State, 2004 WY 57, 90 P.3d 98, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 69 (2004); Ingersoll v. State, 2004 WY 102, 96 P.3d 1046, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 130 (2004); Campbell v. State, 2004 WY 106, 97 P.3d 781, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 135 (2004); Rice v. State, 2004 WY 130, 100 P.3d 371, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 169 (2004); Valle v. State, 2006 WY 43, 132 P.3d 181, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 48 (Wyo. Apr. 12, 2006); Peden v. State, 2006 WY 26, 129 P.3d 869, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 30 (Wyo. Mar. 14, 2006); Hall v. State, 2007 WY 138, 166 P.3d 875, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 149 (Aug. 28, 2007); Abeyta v. State, 2007 WY 142, 167 P.3d 1, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 154 (Sept. 5, 2007); Lawrence v. State, 2007 WY 183, 171 P.3d 517, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 195 (Nov. 15, 2007); Garvin v. State, 2007 WY 190, 172 P.3d 725, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 202 (Dec. 6, 2007); Dee v. State, 2008 WY 17, 177 P.3d 218, 2008 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Feb. 13, 2008); Leyva v. State, 2009 WY 149, 220 P.3d 791, 2009 Wyo. LEXIS 167 (Dec. 9, 2009); Granzer v. State, 2010 WY 130, 239 P.3d 640, 2010 Wyo. LEXIS 140 (Sept. 29, 2010); Graham v. State, 2011 WY 39, 247 P.3d 872, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (Mar. 4, 2011); Washington v. State, 2011 WY 132, 261 P.3d 717, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 137 (Sept. 20, 2011); Landeroz v. State, 2011 WY 168, 267 P.3d 1075, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 176 (Dec. 28, 2011); Mebane v. State, 2012 WY 43, 272 P.3d 327, 2012 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (Mar. 21, 2012); Phelps v. State, 2012 WY 87, 278 P.3d 1148, 2012 Wyo. LEXIS 92 (June 19, 2012); Klomliam v. State, 2014 WY 1, 315 P.3d 665, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 1, 2014 WL 28838 (Jan 3, 2014); Russell v. State, 2013 WY 137, 312 P.3d 76, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 143, 2013 WL 5859618 (Oct 31, 2013); Russell v. State, 2013 WY 137, 312 P.3d 76, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 143, 2013 WL 5859618 (Oct 31, 2013); Engdahl v. State, 2014 WY 76, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 82 (Jun 13, 2014); Cardenas v. State, 2014 WY 92, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 102, 2014 WL 3586509 (Jul 22, 2014); Overson v. State, 2017 WY 4, 386 P.3d 1149, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 2017).

Law reviews. —

For note, “Can You Be Busted for Your Roommate's Pot? Mulligan v. State, 513 P.2d 180, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 175 (Wyo. 1973),” see IX Land & Water L. Rev. 237 (1974).

For case note, “The Entrapment Defense — The Determination of Predisposition. Janski v. State, 538 P.2d 271, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 152 (Wyo. 1975),” see XI Land & Water L. Rev. 265 (1976).

For comment on Stuebgen v. State, 548 P.2d 870, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 181 (Wyo. 1976), cited in case notes, see XII Land & Water L. Rev. 301 (1977).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Admissibility, in criminal prosecution, of expert opinion allegedly stating whether drugs were possessed with intent to distribute — state cases, 83 ALR4th 629.

Validity, construction and effect of state statute regulating sale of counterfeit or imitation controlled substances, 84 ALR4th 936.

Defense of necessity, duress or coercion in prosecution for violation of state narcotics laws, 1 ALR5th 938.

Criminality of act of directing to, or recommending, source from which illicit drugs may be purchased, 34 ALR5th 125.

Sufficiency of evidence that possessor of heroin had intent to distribute it, so as to violate 21 USC § 841 (a)(1) , 78 ALR Fed 413.

§ 35-7-1032. Certain unlawful acts particularly applicable to registrants.

  1. It is unlawful for any person:
    1. Who is subject to Article IV to distribute or dispense a controlled substance in violation of W.S. 35-7-1030;
    2. Who is a registrant, to manufacture a controlled substance not authorized by his registration, or to distribute or dispense a controlled substance not authorized by his registration to another registrant or other authorized person;
    3. To refuse or fail to make, keep or furnish any record, notification, order form, statement, invoice or information required under this act;
    4. To refuse an entry into any premises for any inspection authorized by this act; or
    5. Knowingly to keep or maintain any store, shop, warehouse, dwelling, building, vehicle, boat, aircraft, or other structure or place, which is resorted to by persons using controlled substances in violation of this act for the purpose of using these substances, or which is used for keeping or selling them in violation of this act.

(b) Any person who violates this section is punishable by a civil fine of not more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00); provided, that if the violation is prosecuted by a complaint, information or indictment which alleges that the violation was committed knowingly or intentionally, and the trier of fact specifically finds that the violation was committed knowingly or intentionally such person is punishable by imprisonment for not more than one (1) year or a fine of not more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), or both such fine and imprisonment.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 32; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.32.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 35-7-1002(a)(xxviii).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity, construction and application of state or local law prohibiting maintenance of vehicle for purpose of keeping or selling controlled substances, 31 ALR5th 760.

§ 35-7-1033. Unlawful acts; distribution; registration; possession; records; counterfeiting; punishment. [Effective until July 1, 2024]

  1. It is unlawful for any person knowingly or intentionally:
    1. To distribute as a registrant a controlled substance classified in Schedule I or II, except pursuant to an order form as required by W.S. 35-7-1029;
    2. To use in the course of the manufacture or distribution of a controlled substance a registration number which is fictitious, revoked, suspended, or issued to another person;
    3. To acquire or obtain possession of, to procure or attempt to procure the administration of, or to obtain a prescription for, any controlled substance by misrepresentation, fraud, forgery, deception or subterfuge. The conduct prohibited by this paragraph includes but is not limited to:
      1. Failing to disclose to a practitioner that the person has received the same or similar controlled substance or prescription for a controlled substance from another source within the prior thirty (30) days;
      2. Alteration or forgery of a prescription or written order for a controlled substance; and
      3. The use of a false name or address.
    4. To furnish false or fraudulent material information in, or omit any material information from, any application, report, or other document required to be kept or filed under this act, or any record required to be kept by this act; or
    5. To make, distribute, or possess any punch, die, plate, stone, or other thing designed to print, imprint, or reproduce the trademark, trade name, or other identifying mark, imprint, or device of another or any likeness of the foregoing upon any drug or container or labeling thereof so as to render the drug a counterfeit substance.
  2. Except for a violation of subparagraph (a)(iii)(B) of this section and except as otherwise provided:
    1. A person who is convicted upon a plea of guilty or no contest or found guilty of violating paragraph (a)(iii) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than six (6) months, a fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), or both, and the person may be ordered to receive a substance abuse assessment conducted by a substance abuse provider certified by the department of health pursuant to W.S. 9-2-2701(c) before sentencing;
    2. A person convicted upon a plea of guilty or no contest or found guilty of a second offense of violating paragraph (a)(iii) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than one (1) year, a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or both, and the person shall be ordered to receive a substance abuse assessment conducted by a substance abuse provider certified by the department of health pursuant to W.S. 9-2-2701(c) before sentencing;
    3. A person convicted upon a plea of guilty or no contest or found guilty of a third or subsequent offense of violating paragraph (a)(iii) of this section is guilty of a felony punishable by imprisonment for not more than ten (10) years, a fine of not more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), or both;
    4. In the event a substance abuse assessment ordered pursuant to this section is provided by an entity with whom the department of health contracts for treatment services, the costs of the assessment shall be paid by the offender subject to the sliding fee scale adopted pursuant to W.S. 35-1-620 and 35-1-624; provided however, if the assessment is ordered as a result of a felony conviction under this section, the assessment shall be conducted and costs assessed pursuant to W.S. 7-13-1301, et seq.;
    5. Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the term of probation imposed by a court for a violation of paragraph (a)(iii) of this section for a first or second conviction may exceed the maximum term of imprisonment established for the applicable offense under paragraph (i) or (ii) of this subsection provided the term of probation, together with any extension thereof, shall in no case exceed two (2) years.
  3. Except as otherwise provided, any person who violates this section is guilty of a crime and upon conviction may be imprisoned for not more than five (5) years, or fined not more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), or both.
  4. A person convicted upon a plea of guilty or no contest or found guilty of violating subparagraph (a)(iii)(B) of this section is guilty of a felony punishable by imprisonment for not more than ten (10) years, a fine of not more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), or both.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 33; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.33; 2008, ch. 83, § 1; 2009, ch. 78, § 1; 2021 ch. 79, § 1, effective July 1, 2024.

The 2008 amendment, effective July 1, 2008, rewrote (a)(iii); inserted present (b) and redesignated former (b) as (c); and in (c), inserted the exception at the beginning.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, made stylistic changes in (a)(iii); inserted “or forgery” in (a)(iii)(B); inserted “Except for a violation of subparagraph (a)(iii)(B) of this section and” in the introductory language of (b); and added (d).

The 2021 amendment , effective July 1, 2022, in (b)(iv), substituted “payment policies” for “sliding fee scale” and deleted “and 35-1-624” following “W.S. 35-1-620.”

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 35-7-1002(a)(xxviii).

Double Jeopardy was inapplicable. —

Unpublished decision: State prisoner was not entitled to habeas relief under 28 U.S.C.S. § 2241 because his Double Jeopardy Clause rights were not violated by the refusal of the Wyoming Board of Parole to hold a parole revocation proceeding while he was serving an Arizona sentence after he had absconded while on parole for convictions under Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 35-7-1033 and 35-7-1031. The Double Jeopardy Clause was inapplicable in that the prisoner was serving two separate sentences for convictions in two different states. Vonkrosigk v. Schriro, 384 Fed. Appx. 812, 2010 U.S. App. LEXIS 13412 (10th Cir. Wyo. 2010).

Reliance is not essential aspect of the “fraud” about which subsection (a)(iii) speaks since this crime requires no victim and, therefore, no specific intent to defraud a victim other than the public at large. Cronin v. State, 678 P.2d 370, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 267 (Wyo. 1984); Robinson v. State, 678 P.2d 374, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 274 (Wyo. 1984).

“Prescription Fraud.” —

In a prosecution for conspiring and attempting to knowingly or intentionally acquire or obtain possession of a controlled substance by misrepresentation, fraud, forgery, deception, or subterfuge in violation of this section and § 35-7-1042, use of the term “prescription fraud” to describe the substantive crime in instructions was not plain error. Thomas v. State, 958 P.2d 1059, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 104 (Wyo. 1998).

Sufficient evidence for conviction. —

See Broom v. State, 695 P.2d 640, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 459 (Wyo. 1985).

Cited in

Lafond v. State, 2004 WY 51, 89 P.3d 324, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 61 (2004).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Propriety of lesser–included offense charge in state prosecution of narcotics defendant—Marijuana cases, 1 ALR6th 549.

Propriety of lesser–included offense charge in state prosecution of narcotics defendant—Cocaine cases, 2 ALR6th 551.

§ 35-7-1033. Unlawful acts; distribution; registration; possession; records; counterfeiting; punishment. [Effective July 1, 2024]

  1. It is unlawful for any person knowingly or intentionally:
    1. To distribute as a registrant a controlled substance classified in Schedule I or II, except pursuant to an order form as required by W.S. 35-7-1029;
    2. To use in the course of the manufacture or distribution of a controlled substance a registration number which is fictitious, revoked, suspended, or issued to another person;
    3. To acquire or obtain possession of, to procure or attempt to procure the administration of, or to obtain a prescription for, any controlled substance by misrepresentation, fraud, forgery, deception or subterfuge. The conduct prohibited by this paragraph includes but is not limited to:
      1. Failing to disclose to a practitioner that the person has received the same or similar controlled substance or prescription for a controlled substance from another source within the prior thirty (30) days;
      2. Alteration or forgery of a prescription or written order for a controlled substance; and
      3. The use of a false name or address.
    4. To furnish false or fraudulent material information in, or omit any material information from, any application, report, or other document required to be kept or filed under this act, or any record required to be kept by this act; or
    5. To make, distribute, or possess any punch, die, plate, stone, or other thing designed to print, imprint, or reproduce the trademark, trade name, or other identifying mark, imprint, or device of another or any likeness of the foregoing upon any drug or container or labeling thereof so as to render the drug a counterfeit substance.
  2. Except for a violation of subparagraph (a)(iii)(B) of this section and except as otherwise provided:
    1. A person who is convicted upon a plea of guilty or no contest or found guilty of violating paragraph (a)(iii) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than six (6) months, a fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), or both, and the person may be ordered to receive a substance abuse assessment conducted by a substance abuse provider certified by the department of health pursuant to W.S. 9-2-2701(c) before sentencing;
    2. A person convicted upon a plea of guilty or no contest or found guilty of a second offense of violating paragraph (a)(iii) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than one (1) year, a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or both, and the person shall be ordered to receive a substance abuse assessment conducted by a substance abuse provider certified by the department of health pursuant to W.S. 9-2-2701(c) before sentencing;
    3. A person convicted upon a plea of guilty or no contest or found guilty of a third or subsequent offense of violating paragraph (a)(iii) of this section is guilty of a felony punishable by imprisonment for not more than ten (10) years, a fine of not more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), or both;
    4. In the event a substance abuse assessment ordered pursuant to this section is provided by an entity with whom the department of health contracts for treatment services, the costs of the assessment shall be paid by the offender subject to the payment policies adopted pursuant to W.S. 35-1-620; provided however, if the assessment is ordered as a result of a felony conviction under this section, the assessment shall be conducted and costs assessed pursuant to W.S. 7-13-1301, et seq.;
    5. Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the term of probation imposed by a court for a violation of paragraph (a)(iii) of this section for a first or second conviction may exceed the maximum term of imprisonment established for the applicable offense under paragraph (i) or (ii) of this subsection provided the term of probation, together with any extension thereof, shall in no case exceed two (2) years.
  3. Except as otherwise provided, any person who violates this section is guilty of a crime and upon conviction may be imprisoned for not more than five (5) years, or fined not more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), or both.
  4. A person convicted upon a plea of guilty or no contest or found guilty of violating subparagraph (a)(iii)(B) of this section is guilty of a felony punishable by imprisonment for not more than ten (10) years, a fine of not more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), or both.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 33; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.33; 2008, ch. 83, § 1; 2009, ch. 78, § 1; 2021 ch. 79, § 1, effective July 1, 2024.

§ 35-7-1034. Penalties are additional.

Any penalty imposed for violation of this act is in addition to, and not in lieu of, any civil administrative penalty or sanction otherwise authorized by law.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 34; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.34.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 35-7-1002(a)(xxviii).

§ 35-7-1035. Conviction or acquittal under federal law or law of another state.

If a violation of this act is a violation of a federal law or a law of another state, a conviction or acquittal under federal law or the law of another state for the same act is a bar to prosecution in this state.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 35; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.35.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 35-7-1002(a)(xxviii).

§ 35-7-1036. Distribution to person under 18; drug free school zones.

  1. Any person eighteen (18) years of age or over who violates W.S. 35-7-1031(a) by distributing methamphetamine or a controlled substance listed in Schedules I or II which is a narcotic drug to a person under eighteen (18) years of age who is at least three (3) years his junior is punishable by the fine authorized by W.S. 35-7-1031(a)(i), by a term of imprisonment of up to twice that authorized by W.S. 35-7-1031(a)(i), or both. Any person eighteen (18) years of age or over who violates W.S. 35-7-1031(a) by distributing any other controlled substance listed in Schedules I, II, III, to a person under eighteen (18) years of age who is at least three (3) years his junior is punishable by the fine authorized by W.S. 35-7-1031(a)(ii), by a term of imprisonment up to twice that authorized by W.S. 35-7-1031(a)(ii), or both. Any person eighteen (18) years of age or over who violates W.S. 35-7-1031(a) by distributing any controlled substance listed in Schedule IV to a person under eighteen (18) years of age who is at least three (3) years his junior is punishable by the fine authorized by W.S. 35-7-1031(a)(iii), by a term of imprisonment up to twice that authorized by W.S. 35-7-1031(a)(iii), or both. Any person eighteen (18) years of age or over who violates W.S. 35-7-1031(a) by distributing any controlled substance listed in Schedule V to a person under eighteen (18) years of age who is at least three (3) years his junior is punishable by the fine authorized by W.S. 35-7-1031(a)(iv), by a term of imprisonment up to twice that authorized by W.S. 35-7-1031(a)(iv), or both.
  2. Any person who is convicted of any of the following listed offenses with regard to a controlled substance listed in Schedules I through IV shall have the penalties specified in this subsection imposed as part of the sentence and in addition to any other penalties authorized by law, if that offense was committed within any school bus as defined in W.S. 31-7-102(a)(xl) or within the boundaries of or within five hundred (500) feet of the boundaries of real property used by a school district primarily for the education of any student in any grade from kindergarten through twelfth grade:
    1. If an adult:
      1. For manufacture, delivery or possession with intent to manufacture or deliver in violation of W.S. 35-7-1031(a) or subsection (a) of this section:
        1. Imprisonment for a minimum of two (2) years; and
        2. An additional fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
      2. For possession in violation of W.S. 35-7-1031(c) an additional fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00).
    2. If a minor and if not sentenced to a term of imprisonment which is unsuspended:
      1. For manufacture, delivery or possession with intent to manufacture or deliver in violation of W.S. 35-7-1031(a):
        1. Successful completion of a drug education or rehabilitation program specified by the court;
        2. Not less than twenty-five (25) nor more than two hundred (200) hours of community service specified by the court; and
        3. Submission to monthly drug testing for one (1) year.
      2. For possession in violation of W.S. 35-7-1031(c):
        1. Successful completion of a drug education or rehabilitation program specified by the court;
        2. Not less than twenty-five (25) nor more than one hundred (100) hours of community service specified by the court; and
        3. Submission to monthly drug testing for six (6) months.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 36; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.36; Laws 1991, ch. 232, § 1; 1999, ch. 40, § 1; 2014 ch. 79, § 1, effective March 10, 2014.

The 2014 amendment, in (b), substituted “31-7-102(a)(xl)” for “31-7-102(a)(xix).”

Laws 2014, ch. 79, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 10, 2014.

Editor's notes. —

The bracketed reference has been inserted in the introductory language in (b) as it is the apparent intended reference.

Intent to deliver. —

Defendant's admission to the detective that she lit her marijuana pipe and was passing it to two other people when the deputies arrived in her trailer showed her specific intent to deliver marijuana. Hughes v. State, 2003 WY 35, 65 P.3d 378, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 43 (Wyo. 2003).

Incarceration justified for defendant selling drugs to youth and not accepting responsibility. —

Where the prosecutor and investigation report recommended incarceration, and there was testimony indicating that defendant had been selling drugs to young people and that he was unwilling to accept responsibility for his acts, the court did not abuse its discretion in sentencing defendant to incarceration. Yates v. State, 723 P.2d 37, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 592 (Wyo. 1986).

Evidence sufficient to prove delivery. —

Where police officers responded to a report that the odor of burning marijuana was emanating from an apartment where minors were present, defendant retrieved from her bedroom a wooden box containing a small amount of marijuana and other paraphernalia. The corporal testified that three juveniles admitted that they had smoked marijuana and defendant admitted that she supplied the drugs; the evidence was sufficient to support defendant's conviction for three felony counts of delivery of a controlled substance to a minor in violation of this section. Anderson v. State, 2009 WY 119, 216 P.3d 1143, 2009 Wyo. LEXIS 130 (Wyo. 2009).

Quoted in

White v. Board of Trustees, 648 P.2d 528, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 361 (Wyo. 1982).

Cited in

Lobatos v. State, 875 P.2d 716, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 68 (Wyo. 1994).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity, construction and application of state statutes prohibiting sale or possession of controlled substances within specified distance of schools, 27 ALR5th 593.

Validity, Construction, and Application of State Statutes Enhancing Penalty for Sale or Possession of Controlled Substances Within Specified Distance of Playgrounds. 23 A.L.R.6th 679.

§ 35-7-1037. Probation and discharge of first offenders.

Whenever any person who has not previously been convicted of any offense under this act or under any statute of the United States or of any state relating to narcotic drugs, marihuana, or stimulant, depressant, or hallucinogenic drugs, pleads guilty to or is found guilty of possession of a controlled substance under W.S. 35-7-1031(c) or 35-7-1033(a)(iii)(B), or pleads guilty to or is found guilty of using or being under the influence of a controlled substance under W.S. 35-7-1039, the court, without entering a judgment of guilt and with the consent of the accused, may defer further proceedings and place him on probation upon terms and conditions. Any term of probation imposed under this section for a felony offense shall not exceed the maximum term of probation authorized under W.S. 7-13-302(b). Upon violation of a term or condition, the court may enter an adjudication of guilt and proceed as otherwise provided. Upon fulfillment of the terms and conditions, the court shall discharge the person and dismiss the proceedings against him. Discharge and dismissal under this section shall be without adjudication of guilt and is not a conviction for purposes of this section or for purposes of disqualifications or disabilities imposed by law upon conviction of a crime, including the additional penalties imposed for second or subsequent convictions under W.S. 35-7-1038. There may be only one (1) discharge and dismissal under this section with respect to any person. This section shall not be construed to provide an exclusive procedure. Any other procedure provided by law relating to suspension of trial or probation, may be followed, in the discretion of the trial court.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 37; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.37; 2009, ch. 78, § 1; 2015 ch. 37, § 1, effective July 1, 2015; 2019 ch. 101, § 1, effective July 1, 2019.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, inserted “or 35-7-1033(a)(iii)(B).”

The 2015 amendment, effective July 1, 2015, inserted “or pleads guilty to or is found guilty of using or being under the influence of a controlled substance under W.S. 35-7-1039” in the first sentence.

The 2019 amendment, effective July 1, 2019, added the second sentence.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 35-7-1002(a)(xxviii).

Applicability

Laws 2019, ch. 101 § 2, provides: "The provisions of this act shall apply to all persons who are sentenced or placed on probation pursuant to W.S. 7-13-301, 7-13-302 and 35-7-1037 on or after the effective date of this act."

Evidence sufficient to discharge railroad employee following guilty plea. —

See United Transp. Union (C) & (T) v. Union P. R. Co., 593 F. Supp. 1193, 1984 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 23473 (D. Wyo. 1984), aff'd, 812 F.2d 630, 1987 U.S. App. LEXIS 2507 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1987).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Under what circumstances should total weight of mixture or substance in which detectable amount of controlled substance is incorporated be used in assessing sentence under United States Sentencing Guideline § 2D1.1—post-Chapman cases, 113 ALR Fed 91.

§ 35-7-1038. Second or subsequent offenses; mandatory minimum penalty for certain subsequent offenses.

  1. Unless otherwise provided under W.S. 35-7-1031(c), any person convicted of a second or subsequent offense under this act may be imprisoned for a term up to twice the term otherwise authorized, fined an amount up to twice that otherwise authorized, or both. The judge may suspend part or all of the discretionary portion of an imprisonment sentence or fine under this subsection and place the defendant on probation pending successful completion, at the defendant’s own expense, of a chemical addiction evaluation or treatment program prescribed by the judge.
  2. For purposes of subsection (a) of this section, an offense is a second or subsequent offense if, prior to his conviction of the offense, the offender has at any time been convicted under this act or under any statute of the United States or of any state relating to narcotic drugs, marijuana, depressant, stimulant or hallucinogenic drugs.
  3. This section shall not apply to offenses under W.S. 35-7-1031(c).

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 38; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.38; Laws 1995, ch. 61, § 1.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 35-7-1002(a)(xxviii).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Under what circumstances should total weight of mixture or substance in which detectable amount of controlled substance is incorporated be used in assessing sentence under United States Sentencing Guideline § 2D1.1—post-Chapman cases, 113 ALR Fed 91.

§ 35-7-1039. Person using or under influence of controlled substance.

Any person who knowingly or intentionally uses or is under the influence of a controlled substance listed in Schedules I, II or III except when administered or prescribed by or under the direction of a licensed practitioner, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by imprisonment in the county jail not to exceed six (6) months or a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), or by both.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 39; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.39; Laws 2004, ch. 87, § 1.

The 2004 amendment, effective July 1, 2004, substituted “six (6) months” for “ninety (90) days,” and “seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00)” for “one hundred dollars ($100.00).”

Merger. —

When appellant was convicted of possession of a controlled substance precursor with the intent to engage in a clandestine laboratory operation in violation of this section, conspiracy to engage in a clandestine laboratory operation, and two counts of child endangerment, he was sentenced to terms of six to eight years imprisonment on each of the first two counts, with the two sentences to run concurrently. Appellant was sentenced to terms of eighteen to twenty-four months on each of the last two counts, with these two sentences to run concurrently, but consecutive to the sentences on the first two charges; the district court was not required to merge the different crimes for sentencing under the Blockburger test, because the offenses were different as each required proof of an element that the other did not. Baker v. State, 2011 WY 123, 260 P.3d 268, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 127 (Wyo. 2011).

Quoted in

White v. Board of Trustees, 648 P.2d 528, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 361 (Wyo. 1982).

Stated in

United States v. Blucher, 581 F.2d 244, 1978 U.S. App. LEXIS 9897 (10th Cir. 1978).

Cited in

Dee v. State, 2008 WY 17, 177 P.3d 218, 2008 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Feb. 13, 2008).

§ 35-7-1040. Planting, cultivating or processing marihuana, peyote or opium poppy.

Any person who knowingly or intentionally plants, cultivates, harvests, dries, or processes any marihuana, peyote, or opium poppy except as otherwise provided by law shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by imprisonment not to exceed six (6) months in the county jail or by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or both.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 40; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.40.

Cited in

Dee v. State, 2008 WY 17, 177 P.3d 218, 2008 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Feb. 13, 2008).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Constitutionality of state legislation imposing criminal penalties for personal possession or use of marijuana, 96 ALR3d 225.

§ 35-7-1041. Distribution of liquid, substance or material in lieu of controlled substance.

Any person who in any manner offers to unlawfully sell, furnish, transport, administer, or give any controlled substance to any person, or offers, arranges, or negotiates to have any controlled substance unlawfully sold, delivered, transported, furnished, administered, or given to any person and then sells, delivers, furnishes, transports, administers, or gives, or offers, arranges, or negotiates to have sold, delivered, transported, furnished, administered or given to any person any other liquid, substance, or material in lieu of any controlled substance shall be punished by imprisonment for not more than (1) year, or fined not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or by both such fine and imprisonment.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 41; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.41.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Products liability: recovery for injury or death resulting from intentional inhalation of product's fumes or vapors to produce intoxicating or similar effect, 50 ALR5th 275.

§ 35-7-1042. Attempts and conspiracies.

Any person who attempts or conspires to commit any offense under this article within the state of Wyoming or who conspires to commit an act beyond the state of Wyoming which if done in this state would be an offense punishable under this article, shall be punished by imprisonment or fine or both which may not exceed the maximum punishment prescribed for the offense the commission of which was the object of the attempt or conspiracy.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 42; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.42.

Evidence sufficient.—

There was sufficient evidence to support defendant’s conviction for conspiracy to delivery a controlled substance such that a jury could reasonably infer from the facts before it that defendant had an individual connection with, and an appreciable ability to guide the destiny of the over 74 pounds of marijuana found in his compact car packaged in a form consistent with delivery, and producing a strong smell. Mitchell v. State, 2020 WY 142, 476 P.3d 224, 2020 Wyo. LEXIS 166 (Wyo. 2020).

Subject matter jurisdiction over conspiracy. —

The trial court had jurisdiction over a prosecution for conspiracy to deliver a controlled substance, conspiracy to possess a controlled substance with intent to deliver, and conspiracy to possess a controlled substance where the defendant was stopped on a highway in Colorado while en route to deliver marijuana to a coperpetrator in Wyoming, notwithstanding that the conspiracies were not entered into in Wyoming and that the defendant committed no criminal acts in Wyoming, as there was an intent for the conspiracies to have an effect in Wyoming. Marquez v. State, 12 P.3d 711, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 216 (Wyo. 2000).

Overt act is not essential element of crime of conspiracy. Apodaca v. State, 627 P.2d 1023, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 351 (Wyo. 1981).

Possession and attempted possession with intent to deliver may be charged and tried together. —

It was proper for the indictment to charge possession of a controlled substance with intent to deliver and attempted possession of a controlled substance with intent to deliver, and it was also proper that both alleged violations be tried in one proceeding because they were of similar character and based on the same act or transaction or, at the very least, on two or more acts or transactions connected together or constituting part of a common scheme or plan. Jerskey v. State, 546 P.2d 173, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 170 (Wyo. 1976). See Rule 11 (a), W.R. Crim. P.

But conviction may only be on 1 count. —

Where the indictment charged defendant with possession of a controlled substance with intent to deliver and attempted possession of a controlled substance with intent to deliver, even though both counts could be brought under the same complaint (both counts could be tried at the same time, the same witnesses could testify in the proof of each charge insofar as their testimony was relevant, material and competent, or otherwise admissible, and the same evidence could be received to support each count), the defendant could not be convicted and sentenced to prison for more than one offense. There was but one transaction, one common scheme or plan, and, because one offense was merged with another, the convictions may not be stacked because the result would be to have twice placed the defendant in jeopardy in that he would have received multiple punishment for the same offense at one trial. Jerskey v. State, 546 P.2d 173, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 170 (Wyo. 1976).

This section and § 35-7-1031 (delivery) are directed at separate evils. The delivery statute targets the delivery of drugs while the conspiracy statute is directed at prevention of partnerships in crime. Refusal to merge counts under the two statutes would therefore not involve a double jeopardy violation. Dorador v. State, 768 P.2d 1049, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (Wyo. 1989).

Interdependence element is not germane when evidence reveals only single two-party conspiracy, and where only one conspiracy existed. Gilliam v. State, 890 P.2d 1104, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 1995).

Fatal variance in information. —

Where defendant who lived in California sold drugs to Wyoming residents in California, to be sold in Wyoming, and was convicted of conspiracy with intent to deliver methamphetamine, but the information alleged that “the conspiratorial agreement occurred in Wyoming or defendant conspired to commit an act beyond the State of Wyoming,” the failure to include an element of the offense charged in the information, that a conspiracy occurred that was intended to have had an effect in Wyoming, was a fatal variance, which a detailed affidavit could not cure. Estrada-Sanchez v. State, 2003 WY 45, 66 P.3d 703, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 56 (Wyo. 2003).

“Prescription Fraud.” —

In a prosecution for conspiring and attempting to knowingly or intentionally acquire or obtain possession of a controlled substance by misrepresentation, fraud, forgery, deception, or subterfuge in violation of § 35-7-1033 and this section, use of the term “prescription fraud” to describe the substantive crime in instructions was not plain error. Thomas v. State, 958 P.2d 1059, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 104 (Wyo. 1998).

No standing to challenge search of vehicle. —

Where an informant told law enforcement officers that he had recently been in defendant's residence and purchased methamphetamine from defendant the night before, a deputy went to the home of defendant's fiancee's mother and observed a vehicle in the driveway matching the informant's description of the car driven; during a search of the vehicle, the deputy found drug paraphernalia and more than 20 ounces of marijuana. Defendant lacked standing to challenge the search of his fiancee's vehicle because he had no expectation of privacy in the vehicle; following the denial of his suppression motion, defendant entered a nolo contendere plea to conspiracy to distribute marijuana in violation of this section and possession of marijuana with intent to deliver. Miller v. State, 2009 WY 125, 217 P.3d 793, 2009 Wyo. LEXIS 137 (Wyo. 2009).

Evidence sufficient. —

There was sufficient evidence to uphold defendant's conviction for conspiracy to deliver a controlled substance where the defendant's co-conspirator testified that the co-conspirator and the defendant were engaged in an ongoing source-to-middleman for resale relationship that was mutually beneficial and that the co-conspirator had known the defendant for a number of years and had sold drugs to him repeatedly for his personal use and for resale. Wehr v. State, 841 P.2d 104, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 161 (Wyo. 1992).

Evidence was sufficient to convict a defendant for conspiracy to distribute marijuana where the defendant admitted that he attended a meeting to discuss the distribution of marijuana and was present while sales of marijuana took place. Urrutia v. State, 924 P.2d 965, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 136 (Wyo. 1996).

Where numerous witnesses admitted to using and selling methamphetamine which they bought from defendant, defendant's conviction of conspiracy to deliver a controlled substance, in violation of Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 35-7-1042 and 35-7-1031(a)(i), was affirmed; there was sufficient evidence that defendant conspired with at least three people to deliver the drug. Adams v. State, 2003 WY 152, 79 P.3d 526, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 182 (Wyo. 2003).

Testimony of informant that defendant agreed to procure morphine for her, recording of discussions between informant and defendant throughout the course of their transaction, and defendant's statements to investigators that he was on his way to get morphine but changed his mind when he discovered he was being followed constituted sufficient evidence for jury to conclude defendant had an agreement with another person to violate the controlled substances act. Martinez v. State, 943 P.2d 1178, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 111 (Wyo. 1997).

Defendant was properly convicted of conspiracy to possess methamphetamine with the intent to deliver. The agreement of the conspiracy, to regain possession of the half pound of commercial methamphetamine in an accomplice's bag so that the accomplice could sell the methamphetamine, could be reasonably inferred from the communication between the accomplices and defendant regarding what occurred vis a vis the informant. The defendant's intentional or active participation in the conspiracy could reasonably be inferred from the relationship between the defendant and accomplices, the communication between them regarding what occurred vis a vis the informant, the defendant's role in the ensuing discussions at the defendant's residence and in his vehicle, the particular statements attributed to the defendant during these discussions, and the defendant's conduct at his residence and upon leaving the residence. The requisite intent could reasonably be inferred from the foregoing and additional evidence concerning the accomplice's stated purpose in regaining possession of the methamphetamine, the testimony regarding the significance of the quantity of the methamphetamine involved, and the testimony regarding the manner in which the methamphetamine was packaged. Ekholm v. State, 2004 WY 159, 102 P.3d 201, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 206 (Wyo. 2004).

Evidence sufficient to support conspiracy conviction. —

Evidence was sufficient to sustain a conviction for conspiracy to deliver a controlled substance where defendant sold methamphetamine out of an accomplice's motel room with her knowledge, the accomplice negotiated for the informant to buy methamphetamine from defendant at least partially with defendant's knowledge, and defendant delivered to the informant the quantity of methamphetamine agreed to between the informant and the accomplice. In addition, the informant testified that it was defendant who sold her the drugs. Leyo v. State, 2005 WY 92, 116 P.3d 1113, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 109 (Wyo. 2005).

Corroborating evidence not necessary. —

Where numerous witnesses admitted at trial to using and selling methamphetamine which they bought from defendant, defendant's conviction of conspiracy to deliver a controlled substance, in violation of Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 35-7-1042 and 35-7-1031(a)(i), was affirmed, and no corroborating evidence was required; evidence corroborating the co-conspirator's statement is necessary when out-of-court statements of a co-conspirator are utilized but when in-court statements of a co-conspirator are involved, independent evidence of the conspiracy is not required. Adams v. State, 2003 WY 152, 79 P.3d 526, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 182 (Wyo. 2003).

Conviction requires actual agreement. —

The defendant's conviction for conspiracy to deliver marijuana and cocaine was reversed because there was never an actual agreement to deliver these drugs. Where the evidence showed that there was no drug distribution ring to speak of, that there was no one in the business of selling narcotics except the state's informant and that the defendant merely gave or paid money to buy drugs for himself, no agreement was ever reached for conspiracy purposes. Mondello v. State, 843 P.2d 1152, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 192 (Wyo. 1992).

Government agent is not a co-conspirator. —

A defendant cannot be found guilty of conspiring to deliver a controlled substance when the only other member of the alleged conspiracy is a government agent. Palato v. State, 988 P.2d 512, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 154 (Wyo. 1999).

Evidence showing that defendant sold drugs to witnesses in California, hid the drugs somewhere in their vehicle, then followed them to Wyoming to remove the drugs, that the witnesses were provided the drugs on the condition that the witnesses would be paid proceeds from selling them, and that the witnesses later traveled back to California with thousands of dollars paid to defendant was sufficient to support the jury's verdict that there was a conspiracy that intended the drugs would be distributed in Wyoming. Estrada-Sanchez v. State, 2003 WY 45, 66 P.3d 703, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 56 (Wyo. 2003).

Reasonable suspicion and probable cause. —

Motion to suppress was properly denied because a search did not violate the defendants' rights under the U.S. Const. amend. IV or under Wyo. Const. art. I, § 4; a dog sniff was justified by a reasonably articulable suspicion of illegal activity, and the dog's alert provided the officer with probable cause to search the trunk. Yoeuth v. State, 2009 WY 61, 206 P.3d 1278, 2009 Wyo. LEXIS 59 (Wyo. 2009).

Quoted in

Jandro v. State, 781 P.2d 512, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 212 (Wyo. 1989).

Stated in

Burke v. State, 746 P.2d 852, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 550 (Wyo. 1987); Smallfoot v. State, 2012 WY 39, 272 P.3d 314, 2012 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (Mar. 16, 2012).

Cited in

Billis v. State, 800 P.2d 401, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 119 (Wyo. 1990); Wells v. State, 846 P.2d 589, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 203 (Wyo. 1992); Capshaw v. State, 11 P.3d 905, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 197 (Wyo. 2000); Peden v. State, 2006 WY 26, 129 P.3d 869, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 30 (Wyo. Mar. 14, 2006); Lawrence v. State, 2007 WY 183, 171 P.3d 517, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 195 (Nov. 15, 2007); Garvin v. State, 2007 WY 190, 172 P.3d 725, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 202 (Dec. 6, 2007); Klomliam v. State, 2014 WY 1, 315 P.3d 665, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 1, 2014 WL 28838 (Jan 3, 2014); Russell v. State, 2013 WY 137, 312 P.3d 76, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 143, 2013 WL 5859618 (Oct 31, 2013); Russell v. State, 2013 WY 137, 312 P.3d 76, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 143, 2013 WL 5859618 (Oct 31, 2013); Cardenas v. State, 2014 WY 92, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 102, 2014 WL 3586509 (Jul 22, 2014).

Law reviews. —

For article, “The Wyoming Criminal Code Revisited: Reflections after Fifteen Years,” see XXXIII Land and Water L. Rev. 523 (1998).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Proper venue in prosecution under 21 USC § 846 for attempt or conspiracy to violate Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970, 74 ALR Fed 669.

Federal criminal liability of narcotics conspirator for different substantive crime of other conspirator, 77 ALR Fed 661.

Burden of proof and presumptions in tracing currency, bank account, or cash equivalent to illegal drug trafficking so as to permit forfeiture, or declaration as contraband, under state law, 104 ALR5th 229.

§ 35-7-1043. Immunity from prosecution.

All duly authorized peace officers including any special agents or other personnel appointed by the commissioner, and probation and parole agents as defined in W.S. 7-13-401, while investigating violations of this act in performance of their official duties, shall be immune from prosecution under this act. Any person working under the immediate direction, supervision or instruction of a duly authorized peace officer, special agent or other person appointed by the commissioner, may be granted immunity from prosecution under this act by the commissioner. In addition to the foregoing persons, such immunity may also be granted to any person whose testimony is necessary to secure a conviction under this act with the consent of district judge in the district wherein prosecution is to take place. Any person granted immunity under this section shall not be excused from testifying or producing evidence on the ground that the testimony or evidence required of him may tend to incriminate him or subject him to penalty or forfeiture. Any person who except for the provisions of this act, would have been privileged to withhold the testimony given or the evidence produced by him shall not be prosecuted, subjected to any penalty, forfeiture, for or on account of any transaction, matter or thing concerning which, by reason of said immunity, he gave testimony and produced evidence; and no such testimony given or evidence produced shall be received against him in any criminal proceeding. Provided, no person given immunity under this section shall be exempt from prosecution for perjury or contempt committed while giving testimony or producing evidence under compulsion as provided in this section.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 43; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.43; 2011, ch. 30, § 1.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, inserted “and probation and parole agents as defined in W.S. 7-13-401” in the first sentence.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 35-7-1002(a)(xxviii).

Quoted in

Jaramillo v. State, 802 P.2d 872, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 156 (Wyo. 1990).

Cited in

Hall v. State, 851 P.2d 1262, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 88 (Wyo. 1993).

Law reviews. —

For casenote, “Criminal Procedure — Witness Immunity — The Story of a County Attorney Who Said, ‘I Think I Can, I Think I Can,’ and the Brave Little Conscience that Couldn't be Shocked. Gale v. State, 792 P.2d 570, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 48 (Wyo. 1990),” see XXVII Land & Water L. Rev. 191 (1992).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Competency of drug addict or user to identify suspect material as narcotic or controlled substance, 95 ALR3d 972.

Actions by state official involving defendant as constituting “outrageous” conduct violating due process guaranties, 18 ALR5th 1.

§ 35-7-1044. Peyote delivered, possessed or used for religious sacramental purposes.

Nothing in this act shall be construed to prohibit the delivery, possession or use of peyote in natural form, when delivered, possessed or used for bona fide religious sacramental purposes by members of the Native American Church of Wyoming.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 44; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.44.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 35-7-1002(a)(xxviii).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity, construction, and application of Religious Freedom Restoration Act (42 USCS § 2000bb et seq.), 135 ALR Fed 121.

Article VI

  • § 35-7-1045.  Duties and powers of law enforcement officers; search warrants.
  • § 35-7-1046.  Administrative inspection warrants.
  • § 35-7-1047.  Injunctions against violations.
  • § 35-7-1048.  Cooperation with federal and other state agencies.
  • § 35-7-1049.  Forfeitures and seizures generally; property subject to forfeiture.
  • § 35-7-1050.  Burden of proof; liability of officers.
  • § 35-7-1051.  Review of decisions of board or commissioner.
  • § 35-7-1052.  Educational programs; research.

§ 35-7-1045. Duties and powers of law enforcement officers; search warrants.

  1. Notwithstanding the powers conferred upon the attorney general by this act all law enforcement officers within this state shall have the responsibility for the enforcement of this act.
  2. Any special agent designated by the attorney general and any law enforcement officer engaged in the enforcement of this act may:
    1. Carry firearms in the performance of his official duties;
    2. Serve search warrants, arrest warrants, administrative inspection warrants, subpoenas, and summonses issued under the authority of this state;
    3. Make arrests without warrant for any offense under this act committed in his presence, or if he has probable cause to believe that the person to be arrested has committed, or is committing a violation of this act;
    4. Make seizures of property pursuant to this act; and
    5. Perform such other law enforcement duties as the commissioner may designate.
  3. All prosecutions originating under this act shall be the duty and obligation of the district attorney for the county in which the offense occurred.
  4. A search warrant relating to offenses involving controlled substances may be served at any time of the day or night if the judge or district court commissioner issuing the warrant is satisfied that there is probable cause to believe that grounds exist for the warrant and for its service at such time.
  5. Any officer authorized to execute a search warrant relating to offenses involving controlled substances the penalty for which is imprisonment for more than one (1) year may, without notice of his authority and purpose, break open an outer or inner door or window of a building, or any part of the building, or anything therein, only if a district judge or district court commissioner issuing the warrant: (i) is satisfied that there is probable cause to believe that (A) the property sought may and, if such notice is given, will be easily and quickly destroyed or disposed of, or (B) the giving of such notice will immediately endanger the life or safety of the executing officer or another person; and (ii) has included in the warrant a direction that the officer executing it shall not be required to give such notice. Any officer acting under such warrant, shall, as soon as practicable after entering the premises, identify himself and give the reason and authority for his entrance upon the premises.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 45; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.45; Laws 1981, Sp. Sess., Ch. 22, § 1.

Cross references. —

For procedure relating to search warrants, see Rule 41, W.R. Cr. P.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 35-7-1002(a)(xxviii).

Standard of review. —

The standard of review in considering whether a no-knock search warrant was properly issued is similar to the court's review of whether there was probable cause to issue a search warrant; just as when reviewing probable cause, the court shall afford the issuing judge's determination great deference upon appeal and the determination must be reviewed under a totality of the circumstances test. Lobatos v. State, 875 P.2d 716, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 68 (Wyo. 1994).

Test to be applied. —

After concluding probable cause exists to issue a search warrant, the issuing judge should separately consider whether exigent circumstances justify execution of a search warrant without the requirement of first knocking and announcing the purpose for the police presence; the appropriate test is whether the police information obtained in advance shows reasonable cause to believe exigent circumstances as set forth in the statute exist which would endanger the successful execution of the warrant. Lobatos v. State, 875 P.2d 716, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 68 (Wyo. 1994).

Justice's of peace authority to issue search warrant not statutorily limited. —

Inasmuch as a justice of the peace is authorized by Rule 41, W.R. Cr. P., to issue a search warrant in a controlled substance case, such authority is not limited by subsection (d), which only places a condition on the service of the warrant at night. Ehrenborg v. State, 639 P.2d 886, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 287 (Wyo. 1982).

Absent prejudice, no suppression of illegally-seized evidence. —

Although neither the affidavit nor warrant provided the requisite reasonable cause for a search warrant to be served at night, suppression of evidence seized under the warrant was not required, absent any evidence that the defendants were prejudiced by the nighttime service. United States v. Shelton, 742 F. Supp. 1491, 1990 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 10035 (D. Wyo. 1990).

Quoted in

Mason v. United States, 719 F.2d 1485, 1983 U.S. App. LEXIS 15900 (10th Cir. 1983).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Admissibility of evidence discovered in warrantless search of rental property authorized by lessor of such property — state cases, 2 ALR4th 1173; 61 ALR5th 1.

Propriety of execution of search warrant at nighttime, 41 ALR5th 171.

§ 35-7-1046. Administrative inspection warrants.

  1. Issuance and execution of administrative inspection warrants for controlled premises as defined in this section shall be as follows:
    1. Any district court judge or district court commissioner upon proper oath or affirmation showing probable cause, may issue warrants for the purpose of conducting administrative inspections authorized by this act or rules hereunder, and seizures of property appropriate to such inspections. For purposes of the issuance of administrative inspection warrants, probable cause exists upon showing a valid public interest in the effective enforcement of this act, as it relates to the regulation of the legitimate traffic in controlled substances, sufficient to justify administrative inspection of the area, premises, building or conveyance in the circumstances specified in the application for the warrant;
    2. A warrant shall issue only upon an affidavit of a designated officer or employee of the board or of the commissioner having knowledge of the facts alleged, sworn to before the district judge or district court commissioner establishing the grounds for issuing the warrant. If the district judge or district court commissioner is satisfied that grounds for the application exist or that there is probable cause to believe they exist, he shall issue a warrant identifying the area, premises, building, or conveyance to be inspected, the purpose of the inspection, and, if appropriate, the type of property to be inspected, if any. The warrant shall:
      1. State the grounds for its issuance and the name of each person whose affidavit has been taken in support thereof;
      2. Be directed to a person authorized by W.S. 35-7-1045 to execute it;
      3. Command the person to whom it is directed to inspect the area, premises, building, or conveyance identified for the purpose specified and, if appropriate, direct the seizure of the property specified;
      4. Identify the item or types of property to be seized, if any;
      5. Direct that it be served during normal business hours and designate the judge to whom it shall be returned.
    3. A warrant issued pursuant to this section must be executed and returned within ten (10) days of its date unless, upon a showing of a need for additional time, the court orders otherwise. If property is seized pursuant to a warrant, a copy shall be given to the person from whom or from whose premises the property is taken, together with a receipt for the property taken. The return of the warrant shall be made promptly, accompanied by a written inventory of any property taken. The inventory shall be made in the presence of the person executing the warrant and of the person from whose possession or premises the property was taken, if present or in the presence of at least one (1) credible person other than the person executing the warrant. A copy of the inventory shall be delivered to the person from whom or from whose premises the property was taken and to the applicant for the warrant;
    4. The judge or district court commissioner who has issued a warrant shall attach thereto a copy of the return and all papers returnable in connection therewith and file them with the clerk of the district court for the judicial district in which the inspection was made.
  2. The board may make administrative inspections of controlled premises in accordance with the following provisions:
    1. For purposes of this section only, “controlled premises” means:
      1. Places where persons registered or exempted from registration requirements under this act are required to keep records; and
      2. Places including factories, warehouses, establishments, and conveyances in which persons registered or exempted from registration requirements under this act other than an ultimate user are permitted to hold, manufacture, compound, process, sell, deliver, or otherwise dispose of any controlled substance.
    2. When authorized by an administrative inspection warrant issued pursuant to subsection (a) of this section an officer or employee designated by the board or commissioner, upon presenting the warrant and appropriate credentials to the owner, operator, or agent in charge, may enter controlled premises for the purpose of conducting an administrative inspection;
    3. When authorized by an administrative inspection warrant, an officer or employee designated by the board or commissioner may:
      1. Inspect and copy records required by this act to be kept;
      2. Inspect, within reasonable limits and in a reasonable manner, controlled premises and all pertinent equipment, finished and unfinished material, containers, and labeling found therein, and except as provided in paragraph (b)(v) of this section, all other things therein, including records, files, papers, processes, controls, and facilities bearing on violation of this act; and
      3. Inventory any stock of any controlled substance therein and obtain samples thereof.
    4. This section does not prevent the inspection without a warrant of books and records pursuant to an administrative subpoena issued in accordance with the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act [§§ 16-3-101 through 16-3-115] and the rules promulgated thereunder, nor does it prevent entries and administrative inspections, including seizures of property, without a warrant:
      1. If the owner, operator, or agent in charge of the controlled premises consents;
      2. In situations presenting imminent danger to health or safety where a warrant is not constitutionally required;
      3. In situations involving inspection of conveyances if there is reasonable cause to believe that the mobility of the conveyance makes it impracticable to obtain a warrant;
      4. In any other exceptional or emergency circumstance where time or opportunity to apply for a warrant is lacking and a warrant is not constitutionally required; or
      5. In all other situations in which a warrant is not constitutionally required.
    5. An inspection authorized by this section shall not extend to financial data, sales data, other than shipment data, or pricing data, unless the owner, operator, or agent in charge of the controlled premises consents in writing.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 246, § 46; W.S. 1957, § 35-347.46; Laws 2006, ch. 114, § 1.

The 2006 amendment, deleted “or” at the end of (b)(iv)(B).
